Oxford transcription team, 1992-1998: Peter Robinson, Elizabeth Solopova, Lorna Stevenson, with contributions from James McCabe, Hubert Stadler, Cathy Swires, Paul and Maureen Watry, Laura Wright, Diana Wyatt and Simon Horobin
Sheffield transcription team, 1992-1998, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson and Simon Horobin
De Montfort transcription team, 1998-2005: Peter Robinson, Barbara Bordalejo, Orietta Da Rold, Gavin Cole, Pip Willcox, Jennifer Marshall, Takako Kato, Jacob Thaisen, Nicole Green
University of Saskatchewan team, 2010-2013: Peter Robinson and Barbara Bordalejo
Virgina Tech team, led by Daniel W. Mosser
New York University team, led by David Hoover and Martha Rust, 2003-2006.

Brigham Young University transcription team, 1995-2006, led by Paul Thomas: Sara Black, Jessica Cox, Barbara Christiansen, Kerry Clift Spencer*, Heidi Elldredge, Leona Fisher Sankhla, Kela Flint*, Melissa Gallup, Shannon Harris, Rebecca Johnson, Mary Jorgensen, Darin Merrill*, Wesley Pack*, Jared Perkins, Jon Penny, Randall Rogers, Ryan Rowberry*, Sara Slack, Carie Soderquist Jackson*, Kat Southerland, Matt Tenney, Briton Wright, John Young. Asterisks after names denote those who supervised other transcribers.

Adam Mickiewicz University, Poznan, transcription team, 2007-2010: (names to be supplied), with support from Adam Mickiewicz University and the The Polish Ministry for Science and Higher Education, grant N104 045 32/4256.
Nila Vazquez Gonzalez, University of Murcia.
Institute of Book Studies and Textual Research of the University of Münster, Germany, c. 2000-2004,led by Gabriele Müller Oberhauser; transcribed by Ulrike Grassnick.

University of Sheffield, 1994-1999, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson, Orietta Da Rold and Simon Horobin. In partnership with the Canterbury Tales Project, at that time led by Norman Blake in partnership with Peter Robinson and Elizabeth Solopova (up to 1998), and using images and other resources supplied by the Project, the Sheffield team transcribed eight manuscripts in full (Ad3, Corpus, Dd, Gg, Ellesmere, Ha4, Hengwrt, Lansdowne), sections of some seven other manuscripts, and all manuscripts of the Franklin's Tale. No part of these transcripts is contained in this iteration of the Project.

div.l: (base) Duc Parotheus / loued wel Arcite
(base) And hadde hym knowe at Thebes / yeer by yere
(base) And finally / at requeste and prayere
(base) Of Parotheus / withouten any raunsoun
(base) Duc Theseus / hym leet out of prisoun
(base) Frely to goon / wher that hym liste oueral
(base) In swich a gyse / as I yow tellen shal
(base) This was the forward / pleynly for tendite
(base) Bitwixe Theseus / and hym Arcite
(base) That if so weere that Arcite weere yfounde
(base) Euere in his lyf by day / or nyght or stounde
(base) In any contree / of this Theseus
(base) And he weere caught . it was acorded thus
(base) That with a swerd / he sholde lese his heed
(base) Ther nas noon oother / remedye ne reed
(base) But taketh his leue / and homward he hym spedde
(base) Lat hym be war / his nekke lyth to wedde
(base) Hit were a gret thing to telle and to wite
(base) ¶ How greet a sorwe / suffreth now Arcite
(base) The deeth he feeleth / thurgh his herte smyte
(base) He wepeth / wayleth / cryeth pitously
(base) To sleen hymself he wayteth pryuely
(base) He seyde allas / the day that I was born
(base) Now is my prisoun / worse than biforn
(base) Now is me shape / eternally to dwelle
(base) Noght in purgatorie / but in helle
(base) Allas / that euere knew I Parotheus
(base) For ellis / hadde I dwelled with Theseus
(base) Yfettred in his prisoun eueremo
(base) Thanne hadde I been in blisse / and nat in wo
(base) Oonly the sighte of hire / whom that I serue
(base) Thogh that I neuere / hir grace may disserue
(base) Wolde haue suffised / right ynogh for me
(base) ¶ O deere cosyn / Palamon / quod he
(base) Thyn is the victorie / of this auenture
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Ful blisfully / in prisoun maystow dure
(base) In prison ; / nay certes / but in paradys
(base) Wel hath Fortune / yturned thee / the dys
(base) That hast the sighte of hire / and I thabsence
(base) For possible is / syn thow hast hire presence
(base) And art a knyght a worthy and an able
(base) That by som caas / syn Fortune is chaungeable
(base) Thow mayst to thy desir / som tyme atteyne
(base) But I / that am exiled and bareyne
(base) Of alle grace / and in so greet despeyr
(base) That ther nys Erthe / water / fyr / ne Eyr
(base) Ne creature / that of hem maked is
(base) That may me helpe / or do confort in this
(base) Wel oghte I sterue / in wanhope / and distresse
(base) Farwel my lyf / my lust and my gladnesse
(base) ¶ Allas / why pleynen folk so / in cōmmune
(base) On purueiance of god / or of Fortune
(base) That yeueth hem ful ofte / in many a gyse
(base) Wel bettre / than they kan hem self deuyse
(base) ¶ Som man desireth / for to haue richesse
(base) That cause is ofte / of his moerdre / or gret siknesse
(base) And som man wolde / out of his prison fayn
(base) That in his hous / is of his meynee slayn
(base) Infinite harmes / been in this matere
(base) We woot nat what thyng that we prayen heere
(base) We fare as he / that dronke is as a Mous
(base) A dronke man woot wel / he hath an hous
(base) But he noot which the righte wey is thider
(base) And to a dronke man / . the wey is slider
(base) And certes / in this world / so faren we
(base) We seken faste / after felicitee
(base) But we goon wrong ful ofte trewely
(base) Thus may we seyn alle / and nameliche I
(base) That wende / and hadde a greet opinioun
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) That if I myghte / scapen fro prisoun
(base) Thanne hadde I been in ioye / and parfit heele
(base) Ther now / I am exiled fro my wele
(base) Syn that / I may nat seen yow Emelie
(base) I nam but deed / ther nys no remedie
(base) ¶ Vpon that oother syde Palamon
(base) Whan that he wiste / Arcite was agon
(base) Swich sorwe he maketh / that the grete tour
(base) Resowneth / of his yowlyng and clamour
(base) The pure fettres / of his shynes grete
(base) Were / of his bittre salte teeris wete
(base) Allas quod he / Arcita cosyn myn
(base) Of al oure stryf / god woot the fruyt is thyn
(base) Thow walkest now / in Thebes at thy large
(base) And of my wo / thow yeuest litel charge
(base) Thow mayst syn thou hast wisdom / and manhede
(base) Assemblen / al the folk of oure kynrede
(base) And make a werre / so sharp / on this Citee
(base) That by som auenture / or som tretee
(base) Thow mayst haue hire / to lady and to wyf
(base) For whom / that I moste nedes lese my lyf
(base) For as by wey / of possibilitee
(base) Sith thow art at thy large / of prisoun free
(base) And art a lord / greet is thyn auantage
(base) Moore than is myn / that sterue here in a cage
(base) For I moot wepe / and waille whil I lyue
(base) With al the wo / that prison may me yeue
(base) And eek wᵗith peyne / that loue me yeueth also
(base) That doubleth / al my torment and my wo
(base) Ther with / the fyr of Ialousie vp sterte
(base) With Inne his brest and hente hym by the herte
(base) So woodly / that he lyk was to byholde
(base) The Boxtree / or the Asshen dede / and colde
(base) ¶ Thanne seyde he / o crewel goddes / that gouerne
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) This world / with byndyng of youre word eterne
(base) And writen / in the table of Atthamaıı̄unt
(base) Youre parlement . and youre eterne graıı̄unt
(base) What is man kynde / moore vnto yow holde
(base) Than is the sheep / that rowketh in the folde
(base) For slayn is man / right as another beest
(base) And dwelleth eek in prison and arrest
(base) And hath siknesse / and greet aduersitee
(base) And ofte tymes / giltlees pardee
(base) ¶ What gouernance / is in this prescience
(base) That giltlees / tormenteth Innocence
(base) And yet encreeceth this / al my penance
(base) That man is bounden / to his obseruance
(base) For goddes sake / to letten of his wille
(base) Ther as a beest may al his lust fulfille
(base) And whan a beest is deed / it hath no peyne
(base) But man after his deeth / moot wepe and pleyne
(base) Thogh in this world / he haue care and wo
(base) Withouten doute / it moot stonden so
(base) The answere of this / lete I to diuynys
(base) But wel I woot that in this world / greet pyne is
(base) ¶ Allas / I se a serpent or a theef /
(base) That many a trewe man / hath doon mescheef
(base) Goon at his large / and where hym lust may turne
(base) But I moot been in prison / thurgh Saturne
(base) And eek thurgh Iuno / Ialous / and eek wood
(base) That hath destroyed / wel neigh al the blood
(base) Of Thebes / with his waste walles wyde
(base) And Venus / sleeth me / on that oother syde
(base) For Ialousie / and feere / of hym Arcite
(base) ¶ Now wol I stynte / of Palamon alite
(base) And lete hym / in his prisoun stille dwelle
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And of Arcita / forth I wol yow telle
(base) ¶ The Somer / and the nyghtes longe
(base) Encreecen / double wise / the peynes stronge
(base) Bothe of the louere / and the prisoner
(base) I noot which hath / the sorwefuller myster
(base) For soothly for to seyn / this Palamon
(base) Perpetuelly / is dampned to prisoun
(base) In cheynes / and in fettres / to been deed
(base) And Arcite / is exiled / vpon his heed
(base) For eueremo / as out of that contree
(base) Ne neueremo / ne shal his lady see
(base) ¶ Yow loueris / axe I now / this questioun
(base) Who hath the worse / Arcite / or Palamoun
(base) That oon may seen his lady / day by day
(base) But in prisoun / moot he dwelle alway
(base) That oother / where hym list may ride or go
(base) But seen his lady / shal he neuere mo
(base) Now demeth as yow list ye that kan
(base) For I wol telle forth / as I bigan
(base) ¶ Explicit prima pars ~
(base) ¶ Sequitur pars secunda ~
(base) ¶ Whan that Arcite / to Thebes comen was
(base) Ful ofte a day / he swelte / and seyde allas
(base) For seen his lady / shal he neuere mo
(base) And shortly / to concluden al his wo
(base) So muchel sorwe / hadde neuere creature
(base) That is or shal / whil that the world may dure
(base) ¶ His sleep / his mete / his drynke / is hym biraft
(base) That leene he weex / and drye as is a shaft
(base) Hise eyen holwe / and grisly to biholde
(base) His hewe falow / and pale as asshen colde
(base) And solitarie he was / and euere alloone
(base) And waillynge al the nyght . makynge his moone
(base) And if he herde / soong or Instrument
(base) Thanne wolde he wepe / he myghte nat be stent
(base) So feble eek were his spiritz / and so lowe
(base) And chaunged so / that no man koude knowe
(base) His speche / nor his voys / thogh men it herde
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And in his gere / for al the world he ferde
(base) Nat oonly / lyk the loueris maladye
(base) Of Hereos / but rather lyk Manye
(base) Engendred / of humour malencolyk
(base) Biforn his Celle fantastyk
(base) And shortly / turned was / al vp so down
(base) Bothe habit and eek disposicioun
(base) Of hym / this woful louere daun Arcite
(base) ¶ What sholde I al day / of his wo endite
(base) Whanne he endured hadde / a yeer / or two
(base) This cruel torment and this peyne and wo
(base) At Thebes in his contree / as I seyde
(base) Vpon a nyght in sleep / as he hym leyde
(base) Hym thoughte / how that the wynged god Mercurye
(base) Biforn hym stood / and bad hym to be murye
(base) His slepy yerde / in honde he bar vprighte
(base) An hat he wered / vpon his herys brighte
(base) Arrayed was this god / as he took keep
(base) As he was / whan that Argus took his sleep
(base) And seyde hym thus / to Atthenes shaltow wende
(base) Ther is thee shapen / of thy wo an ende
(base) ¶ And with that word / Arcite wook and sterte
(base) Now trewely / how sore that me smerte
(base) Quod he / to Atthenes right now wol I fare
(base) Ne for the drede of deeth / shal I nat spare
(base) To se my lady / that I loue and serue
(base) In hir presence / I recche nat to sterue
(base) ¶ And with that word / he caughte a greet Mirour
(base) And saugh / that chaunged was al his colour
(base) And saugh his visage / al in another kynde
(base) And right anoon / it ran hym in his mynde
(base) That sith his face / was so disfigured
(base) Of maladie / the which he hadde endured
(base) He myghte wel / if that he bar hym lowe
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Lyue in Atthenes / eueremoore vnknowe
(base) And seen his lady / wel ny / day by day
(base) And right anoon / he chaunged his array
(base) And cladde hym / as a poure laborer
(base) And al allone / saue oonly a Squyer
(base) That knew his pryuetee / and al his cas
(base) Which was disgised / pourely as he was
(base) To Atthenes / is he goon / the nexte way
(base) And to the Court he wente vpon a day
(base) And at the gate / he profreth his seruyse
(base) To drugge and drawe / what so men wol deuyse
(base) ¶ And shortly / of this matere / for to seyn
(base) He fil in office / with a Chambreleyn
(base) The which / that dwellyng was wᵗith Emelye
(base) For he was wys / and koude soone espye
(base) Of euery seruant which that serueth here
(base) Wel koude he / hewen wode / and water bere
(base) For he was yong . and myghty for the nones
(base) And ther to / he was strong and byg of bones
(base) To doon / what any wight kan hym deuyse
(base) A yeer / or two / he was in this seruyse
(base) Page of the chambre / of Emelie the brighte
(base) And Philostrate / he seyde that he highte
(base) ¶ But half so wel biloued a man / as he
(base) Ne was ther neuere in Court of his degree
(base) He was so gentil / of condicioun
(base) That thurgh out al the Court was his renoun
(base) They seiden / that it were a charitee
(base) That Theseus / wolde enhauncen his degree
(base) And putten hym / in worshipful seruyse
(base) Ther as he myghte / his vertu excercise
(base) And thus with Inne a while / his name is spronge
(base) Bothe of his dedes / and his goode tonge
(base) That Theseus / hath taken hym so ner
(base) That of his chambre / he made hym a Squier
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And gaf hym gold / to mayntene his degree
(base) And eek men broghte hym / out of his contree
(base) Fro yeer to yeer / ful pryuely his rente
(base) But honestly / and sleighly / he it spente
(base) That no man wondred / how that he it hadde
(base) And thre yeer in this wise / his lyf he ladde
(base) And bar hym so / in pees / and ek in werre
(base) Ther was no man / that Theseus hath derre
(base) And in this blisse / lete I now Arcite
(base) And speke I wole / of Palamon alite
(base) ¶ In derknesse / and horrible / and strong prisoun
(base) This seuen yeer / hath seten Palamoun
(base) Forpyned / what for wo / and for distresse
(base) Who feeleth / double soor / and heuynesse
(base) But Palamon / that loue destreyneth so
(base) That wood out of his wit he gooth for wo
(base) And eek ther to / he is a prisoner
(base) Perpetuelly / nat oonly for a yer
(base) Who koude ryme / in englissh proprely
(base) His martirdom / for sothe it am noght I
(base) Therfore I passe / as lightly / as I may
(base) ¶ It fil / that / in that seuenthe yeer of May
(base) I wylle not taire yow alle the day
(base) The thridde nyght . as olde bokes seyn
(base) That al this storie / tellen moore pleyn
(base) Were it by auenture / or destynee
(base) As whan a thyng is shapen / it shal be
(base) That soone after the mydnyght Palamoun
(base) By helpyng of a freend / brak his prisoun
(base) And fleeth the Citee / faste as he may go
(base) For he hadde yeue / his Gailler drynke so
(base) Of a Clarree / maad of certeyn wyn
(base) With Nercotikes / and opye / of Thebes fyn / /
(base) That al that nyght . thogh that men wolde hym shake
(base) The Gailler sleep / he myghte noght awake
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) How longe Iuno / thurgh thy crueltee
(base) Woltow werreyen / Thebes the Citee
(base) Allas / ybroght is to confusioun
(base) The blood roial / of Cadme and Amphioun
(base) ¶ Of Cadmus / which that was the firste man
(base) That Thebes bulte / and first bigan
(base) And of the Citee / first was crowned kyng
(base) Of his lynage am I / and his of spryng
(base) By verray ligne / as of the stok roial
(base) And now I am / so caytyf and so thral
(base) That he that is / my mortal enemy
(base) I serue hym / as his Squyer pourely
(base) And yet dooth Iuno / me wel moore shame
(base) For I dar noght biknowe myn owen name
(base) But ther as I was wont to highte Arcite
(base) Now highte I Philostrate / noght worth a myte
(base) ¶ Allas thow felle Mars / allas Iuno
(base) Thus hath youre Ire / oure lynage al fordo
(base) Saue oonly me / and wrecched Palamoun
(base) That Theseus / martireth in prisoun
(base) ¶ And oueral this / to sleen me outrely
(base) Loue hath his firy dart so brennyngly
(base) Ystiked / thurgh my trewe careful herte
(base) That shapen was my deeth / erst than my sherte
(base) Ye sleen me with youre eyen / Emelye
(base) Ye been the cause / wherfore that I dye
(base) Of al the remenant of myn oother care
(base) Ne sette I noght . the mountaunce of a tare
(base) So that I koude doon aught . to youre plesaunce
(base) And with that word / he fil down in a traunce
(base) A longe tyme / and afterward he vp sterte
(base) ¶ This Palamoun / that thoughte / that thurgh his herte
(base) He felte a coold swerd / sodeynly glyde
(base) For Ire he quook . no lenger wolde he byde
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And whan that he had herd / Arcites tale
(base) As he were wood / wᵗith face deed and pale
(base) He stirte hym vp / out of the buskes thikke
(base) And seyde Arcite / false traytour wikke
(base) Now art thow hent that louest my lady so
(base) For whom that I haue / al this peyne and wo
(base) And art my blood / and to my conseil sworn
(base) As I ful ofte / haue toold thee her biforn
(base) And hast byiaped here / duc Theseus
(base) And falsly / chaunged hast thy name thus
(base) I wol be deed / or ellis thow shalt dye
(base) Thow shalt noght / loue my lady Emelye
(base) But I wol loue hire oonly / and namo
(base) For I am Palamon / thy mortal foo
(base) And thogh that I / no wepne haue in this place
(base) But out of prisoun / am astert by grace
(base) I drede noght that outher thow shalt dye
(base) Or thow ne shalt noght louen Emelye
(base) Chees which thow wolt or thow shalt noght asterte
(base) ¶ This Arcite / with ful despitous herte
(base) Whan he hym knew / and hadde his tale herd
(base) As fiers as leoun / pulled out his swerd
(base) As fers as a liou saide thus be god that sittith aboue
(base) And seyde thus / by god that sitteth aboue
(base) Nere it that thow art syk and wood for loue
(base) And eek that thow / no wepne hast in this place
(base) Thow sholdest neuere / out of this groue pace
(base) But out of prisoun art y stert by grace
(base) That thow ne sholdest dyen of myn hond
(base) For I diffye / the seuretee and the bond
(base) Which that thow seist that I haue maad to thee
(base) What verray fool / thynk wel that loue is free
(base) And I wol loue hire / maugree al thy myght
(base) ¶ But for as muche / as thow art a worthy knyght
(base) And wilnest to darreyne hire by bataille
(base) Haue here my trouthe / tomorwe I nyl nat faille
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Withouten wityng of any oother wight
(base) That here I wol be founden / as a knyght
(base) And bryngen harneys / right ynogh for thee
(base) And chees the beste / and leef the worste to me
(base) And mete and drynke / this nyght wol I brynge
(base) Ynogh for thee / and clothes for thy beddynge
(base) And if so be / that thow my lady wynne
(base) And sle me in this wode / ther I am Inne
(base) Thow mayst wel haue thy lady / as for me
(base) ¶ This Palamon answerde / I graunte it thee
(base) And thus they been departed / til amorwe
(base) Whan ech of hem / hadde leyd his feith to borwe
(base) ¶ O Cupide / out of alle charitee
(base) O regne / that wolde no felawe haue to thee
(base) Ful sooth is seyd / that loue ne lordshipe
(base) Wol noght his thankes / haue no felaweshipe
(base) Wel fynden that Arcite and Palamoun
(base) ¶ Arcite / is riden anoon / vnto the town
(base) And on the morwe / er it were dayes lyght
(base) Ful priuely / two harneys hath he dyght
(base) Bothe suffisaunt and mete to darreyne
(base) The bataille in the feeld / bitwix hem tweyne
(base) And on his hors / allone / as he was born
(base) He carieth al this harneys / hym biforn
(base) And in the groue / at tyme and place yset
(base) This Arcite / and this Palamon been met
(base) ¶ To chaungen / gan the colour in hir face
(base) Right as the hunterys / in the regne of Trace
(base) That stonden at the gappe / with a spere
(base) Whanne hunted is / the leoun or the Bere
(base) And hereth hym / come russhynge in the greues
(base) And breketh / bothe bowes / and the leues
(base) And thynketh / here cometh my mortal enemy
(base) Withoute faille / he moot be deed / or .I.

(base) For al forgeten is his vasselage
(base) Thanne is it best as for a worthy fame
(base) To dyen / whan he is best of name
(base) ¶ The contrarie of al this / is wilfulnesse
(base) Why grucchen we / why haue we heuynesse
(base) That goode Arcite / of chiualrie flour
(base) Departed is / with duetee / and with honour
(base) Out of this foule prison / of this lyf
(base) Why gruccheth heere / his cosyn and his wyf /
(base) Of his welfare / that loueth hem so weel
(base) Kan he hem thank nay god woot neuer a deel
(base) That bothe his soule / and eek hem self offende
(base) And yet they mowe / hir lustes nat amende
(base) ¶ What may I conclude / of this longe serye
(base) But after wo / I rede vs to be merye
(base) And thanken Iuppiter / of al his grace
(base) And er we / departen from this place
(base) I rede we make / of sorwes two
(base) O parfit Ioye / lastynge euere mo
(base) And loketh now / wher moost sorwe is her Inne
(base) Ther wol I first amenden and bigynne
(base) ¶ Suster quod he / this is my ful assent
(base) With al thauys / heer of my parlement
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) That gentil Palamon / youre owene knyght
(base) That serueth yow / with wyl and herte myght
(base) And euere hath doon / syn ye first hym knewe
(base) That ye shal of youre grace vpon hym rewe
(base) And taken hym / for housbond and for lord
(base) Leen me youre hond / for this is oure acord
(base) Lat se now / of youre wommanly pitee
(base) He is / a kynges brother sone pardee
(base) And thogh he were / a poure Bachiler
(base) Syn he hath serued yow / so many a yeer
(base) And had for yow / so greet aduersitee
(base) It moste been considred / leueth me
(base) For gentil mercy / oghte to passen right
(base) ¶ Thanne seyde he thus / to Palamon the knyght
(base) I trowe / ther nedeth litel sermonyng
(base) To make yow / assente to this thyng
(base) Com neer / and taketh youre lady by the hond
(base) Bitwixe hem / was maad anon the bond
(base) That highte matrymoigne / or mariage
(base) By al the conseil / and the Baronage
(base) And thus / with alle blisse / and melodye
(base) Hath Palamon / ywedded Emelye
(base) And god / that al this world hath wroght
(base) Sende hym his loue / that hath it deere aboght
(base) For now is Palamon / in alle wele
(base) Lyuynge in blisse / in richesse / and in heele
(base) And Emelye / hym loueth so tendrely
(base) And he / hir serueth so gentilly
(base) That was ther no word hem bitwene
(base) Of Ialousie / or any oother teene
(base) Thus endeth Palamon / and Emelye
(base) And god saue / al this faire compaignye Amen

div.l: Whan that the knyght hadde his tale told
In all the compaignye nas ther yong ne old
That he ne seide it was a noble story
And worthi for to be drawe in memory
And namely the gentiles eủer/reychone
Our hoost lowght and swere so mote y gone
This gooth a right vn bokeled is the male
Lat se now who sha telle a nother tale
For trewly the game is wel by gonne
Now telleth ye sir monk if that ye konne
Som what to quyte withthe knyghtes tale
The Miller that for dronken was al pae
So that vnneth vp on his hors he sat
He nold a valen neither hod ne hat
Ne a byden no man for his curtesye
But in pylates vois he gan to crie
And swore by Armes and by blod and bones
I kan a noble tale for the nones
With which I wold now quite the knyghtes tale
Our hoost saw that he was dronken of ale
And seide a byde Robyn leue brother
Som better man shal telle vs first a nother
A byde and lat vs wirken thriftily
By goddes soule quod he that wil nat I
For y wol speke or elles go my weye
Our hoost answerd telle on a deuelweye
Thow art a fool thi wit is oủer/re come
Now herkeneth quod the myller al and some
But first I make a ꝓprotestaciou
That I am dronke I knowe it by my sou
And therfore if that I mys speke or seye
Wite it the Ale of Southwerk y youe preye
For I wol telle a legend and alyf
Both of a karpenter and of his wif
How that a clerk hath set the wrightes cappe
The Reue answerd and seid stynt thi clappe
Lat be thi lewede dronken harlotrie
It is a synne and ek a gret folye
To Appayren any man or hym defame
And ek to brynge wyues in swich mane name
Thow mayst I now of other thinges sayn
This dronken Miller spak ful sone a gayn
And seide leue brother Oswald
Who hath no wyf he is no cokewald
But that I say for that thow art on
There ben ful gode wyues many on
And eủer/ree a thousand good a yeins on badde
That knowest thow wel but if thow be madde
What art thow angri with my tale now
I haue a wif ꝑper/pardee as wel as thow
I nolde for the oxen in my b plogh
Take vp on me more than y noght
As demen of my self that thow were one
I wol by lyue wel that I am none
An housbonde shuld noght be inquisitif
Of goddes pryuytees ne of his wif
So he mow fynde goddes foisou there
Of the remenant nedeth noght to enquere
What shuld y seye but this Millere
He nolde his wordes for no man for bere
But told his cherles tale in his manere
Me thinketh yit that y shuld rehersen here
And therfore eủer/rey gentil wicht I prie
For goddes loue demeth nat that I seye
Of eue entent but for y mot reherce
Her tales al be they better or werce
Or els falsen som of my matere
And therfore who liste it noght to here
Turne ouer the leef and chese a nother tale
For he shal fynd y now grete and smale
Of storia thyng that toucheth gentelles
And ek moralitee and holynes
Blameth noght me yf that ye chese a mys
The Miller is a cherle ye know wel this
So was the reue and many othere mo
And harlotrie thei tolde bothe two
Auyseth you and put me out of blame
And ek men sholde noght make ernest of game
Whilom there was dwellyng in Oxenforde
A riche gnof that gestes held to borde
And of his crafte he was a Carpentere
With hym ther was dwellyng a pore scolere
Had lerned art but al his fantasie
Was torned for to lerne astrologie
And couth a c̉er/reteyn of conclusions
To demen by interogacions
If that men asked hym in c̉er/retein houres
Whan that men shulde haue droght or shoures
Or if men asked hym shal bi falle
Of eury thing I may noght reken alle
The clerk was cleped hendy Nicholas
Of derne loue he couth and of solas
And therto he was sligh and ful pryue
And like a mayden meke for to be
A chambre had he in that hostrie
Allone with outen any compaignye
Ful fetesly dight with herbes sote
And he hym self as is the rote
Of licoris or any setewale
His almageste and bokes gret and smale
His astrelabre longyng for his art
His Augreme stones leyn faire a part
On shelfes couched at his beddes hede
His presse couered with a mantel rede
And al a bove lay a gay sawtryie
On which he made on nyghtes melodye
So swetely that al the chamber rong
And Angeles ad virginem he song
And after that he songe the kynges note
Ful ofte blessed was his mery throte
And thus the mery clerk his tyme spente
After his frendes fyndyng and his rente
This Carpynter had wedded a new wif
Which that he louede more than his lif
Of souentene yeer she was of age
Gelous he was and held hir narow in cage
For she was wilde and yong and he was olde
And demed hym self belike a coke wolde
He knew nat catou for his wit was rude
That bad a man shuld wedde his similitude
And a man shulde wedden after his estate
For youth and elde is often at debate
But sithen he was fallen in the snare
He most endure as other folk his kare
Faire was this yonge wif and ther with al
As any wesel hir body gentil and smal
A seint she wered ybarred al of silk
A barme clothe as whit as any mylk
Vpon her lendes ful of many a gore
Whit was hir smok and branded al by fore
And ek byhynde on hir coler a boute
Of cole blak silk with Inne and ek withoute
div.fw: The tapys of hir whit volupere
div.l: The tapys of hir whit volupere
Were of the same suyt of hir colere
Hir filet brood of silk set ful hye
And sikerly she had a likerous eye
Ful smale y pulled were hir browes two
And they were bent as blak as any sloo
She was ful blisfull more on to see
Than is the newe pere Ionet tree
And softer than the wolle is of a wether
And by hir girdel ther hongeth a pours of lether
Tasseld with silk and perled with latou
In al this world to seken vp and dou
Ther nys no man that couth thenche
So gay a popelet or swiche a wenche
Ful bright was the shynyng of hir hewe
Than in the tour the noble y forged newe
But of hir song it was as loude and yern
As any swalowe sittyng on a bern
And therto she koud skippe and make game
As any kalf or kyd folowyng his dame
Hir mouthe was swete as bragot or meth
Hir hord of Appelles laide in hai or heth
Wynsyng she was as is a Ioly colt
Long as a mast and vpright as a bolt
A broche she bare vp on hir loue coler
As brode as is boce of a bokeler
Her shoes were lased on hir legges hye
She was a pⁱrimerole a pigges nye
For any lord to lyggen in his bedde
Or yit for any good yeman to wedde
Now sir and efte sir so by fel the caas
That on a day this hendy Nycholas
Fel with this wif to rage and playe
Whil that hir housbound was at Osneye
As clerkes ben ful sotel and ful queynt
As preuely he caught hir by the queynt
And seide ywis but I haue my wille
Of derne loue of the lemman y spille
And hild hir hard by the haunch bones
And seide loue my lemman at ones
Or y wil daien also god me saue
And she sprong as a colt doth in the traue
And with hir hed she wried fast a waye
She seid I wil noght kisse you by my feye
Wy let be that quot she lat be Nicholas
Or y wol crye out harrow and a las
Do way youre hondes for your curtesye
This Nicholas gan mcy for to crie
And spake so faire and profred hym so fast
That she hir loue granted hym at last
And swore hir oth by seint Thomas of kent
That she wold be al at his commaundement
Whan that she may hire leiser wel espie
Myn housbond is so ful of Ialousie
But that ye waite wel and be pryue
I wot right wel y nam but ded quod she
Ye most ben ful dern as yn this cas
Nay ther of care you noght quod hendy Nicholas
A clerk had litherly biset his while
But if he couthe a carpenter bygyle
And thus thei ben accordet and y sworn
To waite a tyme as y haue seid biforne
Whan Nicholas had don this eủer/reydele
And thakked hir about hir lendes wele
He kist hir swete and taketh his sawtrie
And playeth fast and maketh melodye
Than fil it so that to the parissh cherche
Cristes owene werkes for to wirche
This good wif went on An holy day
Hir forhed shon as bright as any day
So was hit wasshen whan that she laft hir werk
Now was ther of the parissh churche a clerk
The which that cleped was Absolon
Crulled was his her and as the gold it shon
And strowted as a fanne large and brode
Ful streight and euene lay his Ioly shode
In hosyn rede went fetisly
Iclad he was ful smal and ꝓproprely
Al in a kertel of whit wachet
Ful faire and thik be the poyntes set
And ther vp on had a gay surplice
As whit as is the blossom of the ryse
A meri child he was so good god me saue
Wel couth he let blode and clippe and shaue
And make a chartre of lond or aquitaunce
In twenty mane chouth he trippe and daunce
After the scole of Oxenford thoo
And with his leges casten to and froo
And play songes vp on a smal ribible
Ther to he songe som tyme a loude quynyble
And as wel couthe he pleye vp on a giterne
In al the town nas brewehous ne tauerne
That he ne vseth it with his solace
Ther any gaylerd tapster was
But sothe to sey he was somdel swaymous
Of fartyng and speche daungerous
This absolon that Ioly was and gay
Gooth with a senser on the holy day
Sensyng the wyues of the parissh faste
And many louely loke he on him kaste
And namely on this Carpenters wif .
To loke on hir hym thought a mery lyf .
She was ꝓpropre and swete and lykeroues
I dar wel say if she had ben a mous
And he a cat he wol hir hente a non
This parisshe clerk this Ioly Absolon
Hath in his hert ben swoche a loue longyng
That of no wif toke he non offryng
For curtesie he seide he nold noon
The moone whan hit was nyght ful bright shoon
And Absolon his giterne hath y take
For ꝑper/paramours he thought for to wake
And forth he goth Iolyf and amorous
Til he cam to the carpenters hous
A litel after the kokkes had y crowe
And dressid him vp by a shop wyndowe
That was vp on the carpenters wal
Hye settyng his voys gentil and smal
Now dere lady if thi wille bee
I pray you that ye wol rewe on mee
Ful wel accordyng to his git̉er/reyng
This Carpenter a wook and herd hym syng
And spake vn to his wif and seid a non
What Alison herst thow noght Absolou
That chaunteth thus vnder our boures wal
And she answerd and seid here husbond therwith all
Yis god woot Iohn I here it eủer/rey del
This passhet forth what wole ye but wel
From day to day this Ioly Absolou
So loueth hir that hym ys wo bygou
He waleth al the nyght and al the day
He kembeth his lokkes brode and made hym gay
He woweth hir by menes and by brokage
He swore he wold be hir owen page
And syngyn brokkynges as a nyghtyngale
He sent hir pinnys and ol spiced ale
And waufours pipyng hote out of the glede
For she was of the toun he proferd hir mede
For somme folk wole be wowed for richesse
And somme for strokes and som for gentillesse
Som tyme to swe shew his lightnesse and his maistrie
He pleyed herawde vp on a Scaffolt hie
But what availeth him in this cas
She loued so this hendy Nicholas
That Absolon may blowe the bokkes horn
He ne had for his labour but a scorn
And thus she maketh Absolon hir Ape
And al his ernest turneth in to a Iape
Ful soth is this prouerbe and no lye
Men seith right thus al way the nye slye
Maketh the fer leef to be looth
Whether tha absolon be wood or wroth
Be cause that he was from hir sight
This nyght Nicholas stood in his light
Now bere the wel thow hend Nicholas
For Absolou may wepe and synge allas
And so byfel that on a saterday
This carpenter was goon to osnay
And heend Nicholas and alisou
Accorded ben to this conclusiou
That Nicholas shal shape hym a wyle
This sely Ialouse housbond to begile
And if so be this game weend a right
She shold slepe in his armes al nyght
For this was hir desir and his also
And right a non with outen wordes mo
This Nicholas wolde no lenger tarie
But doth ful softe to his chambre carie
Both mete and drynke for a day or twey
And h to hir housbond bad for to seye
If that he axed After Nicholas
She shulde sey she wist neủer/ree where he was
Of al the day she sagh hym noght with eye
She trowed that he was in som maladye
For no crie hir mayd couth hym calle
He nolde answere for no thyng that myght falle
This passeth forth al thilk Satirday
That Nicholas stille in his Chamber lay
And ete and sleep and did what hym lyst
Tyl sonday that the sonne gooth to reste
This sely Carpenter hath so gret meruayll
Of Nicholas what thyng myght hym ayll
And seid y am a dred by seynt Thomas
It stont nat a right with Nicholas
God schelde that he deyed sodenly
This world is now ful fikel sekerly
I saw to day a corps y bore to chirche
That now on monday last I shaw him wirche
Go vp quod he to his knaue anou
Clepe at his dore or knok with a stou
Loke how it is and telle me boldely
This knaue gooth hym vp ful sturdely
And atte chambere dore whille that he stode
He cried and knokked as that he were wode
What how now what do ye maister Nicholay
How may ye slepe al the longe day
But al for noght he herde neủer/ree a word
An hole he fond ful low vp on a bord
Ther as the katte was wont in to crepe
And at the hole he loked in ful depe
And atte laste he had of hym a sight
This Nicholas sat eủer/ree gapynge vp right
As he had loked on the newe mone
And dou he goth and tolde his maister sone
As I haue loked in the mone bright
That now a monday next at quart̉er/re nyght
Shall falle a rayne and that so wilde and wood
That half so gret was neủer/ree Nowoles flood
This world he seide in lasse than in an hour
Shal be al dreynt so hidous is the shour
Thus shal man kynde drenche and lese hir lif
This Carpenter answerede allas my wif
And shal she drenche allas myn Alisou
For sorwe of this he fil al moost a dooun
And seid is ther no remedy in this cas
Whi yis for god quod hendy Nicholas
If thow wolt werken after lore and reed
Thow maist nat werken after thin owene hed
For thus seith Salamon that was ful trewe
Werk al by conseil and thow shalt nat rewe
And if thow wolt werken by gode conseil
I vndertake with outen mast or seil
Yit shal I saue hir and me and the
Hastow nat herd how saued was Noe
Whan that oure lord had warned him byforn
That al the world with water shulde be lorn
Yis quod this Carpenter ful yore a goo
Hastow nat herd quod Nicholas also
The sorwe of Noe with his feloweshep
Er that he myght gete his wif to ship
Him had be leủer/re y dar wel vnder take
At thilke tyme than ale his whethers blake
That she hadde had a ship hir self allone
And therfore wostow what is best to doone
This asketh hast and of hastif thing
Men may nat pche ne maken tariyng
A non go gete vs faste in to this In
A knedynge trogh or elles a kemelyn
For eche of vs but loke that they be large
In whiche we mowen swymmen as in a barge
And han ther Ine vitaille suffisant
But for a day fy on the remenaunt
The wat̉er/re shall aslake and gon a way
Aboute pryme vp on the nexte day
But Robyn may not wete this thi knaue
Ne ek thi maide Gil y may nat saue
Axe noght whi for thogh thow axe me
I wolnot tellen goddes pryuetee
Suffiseth thee but if thi wittes madde
To haue as gret a grace as Noe hadde
Thi wif shal I wel sauen oute of doute
Go now thi wey and sped the her a boute
But whan thow hast for hire and the and me
I geten vs thise knedyng tubbes thre
Than shaltow hengen hem in the roof ful heye
That no man of our purueyance espie
And whan thow hast thus doon as I haue seid
And hast oure vitaille faire in him ylayd
And eke an axe to smyte the corde a two
And breke an hol an heigh vp on the gable
Vn to the gardayn ward oủer/re the stable
That we may frely passen forth our wey
Whan that the grette shour is goon a wey
Than shaltow swymme as murie y vndertake
As doth the white doke after hir drake
Than wolle y clepe how Alison how Iohn
Be merie for the flood shal passe a non
And thow wolt seien hail maist̉er/re Nicholay
Good morwe I se the wel for hit is day
Thane shal we be lordes al oure lif
Of al the world as Noe and his wif
But of o thyng I warne the ful right
Be wel auysed on that ilke nyght
That we been entred in to shippes bord
That noon of hus ne speke noght a word
Ne clepe ne crie but ben in his preyere
For it is goddes owene hest deere
Thi wif and thow moote hange fer a twynne
For that be twixe you shal be no synne
No more in lokyng / than ther shal in dede
This ordenaunce is seid go god the spede
To morowe at nyght whan men ben al aslepe
In to oure knedyng / tubbes wol we crepe
And sittyng there a bydyng goddes grace
Go now thi wey I haue no lenger space
To make of this no lenger tariyng
Men seien thus send the wise and sei no thing
Thow art so wise it nedith thee nat theche
Go saue oure lyf and that y the beseche
This sely Carpenter gooth forth his wey
Ful ofte he seide allas and weilaway
And to his wif he tolde his pryuetee
And she was war and knew it bet than hee
What al this quynte cas was for to seie
But natheles she ferd as she wolde deie
And seid seid allas go forth thy wey a non
Help vs to schape or we been dede echon
I am thi trewe verry wedded wif
Go deere spose and help to saue oure lif
Lo whiche a gret thing is affecciou
Men may demen of ymaginaciou
So depe may yn pressiou be take
This sely carpenter bygynneth quake
Him thynketh v̉er/reailiche that he may see
Noes flood come walowyng as the see
To drenchen Alisou his hony deere
He wepeth waileth and maketh sory chiere
He siketh with ful many a sory swogh
And goth and geteth him a knedyng trogh
And aftir a tobbe and a kymelyn
And pryuely he sent hem to his In
And heeng hem in the roof in pryuetee
His owene hnd he made laddres three
To clembien by the ronges and by the stalkes
Vn to the tobbes hongyng by the balkes
And vitailed both trogh and tubbe
Wyth breed and chese and good al in a Iubbe
Suffisinge right y now as for a day
But er that he hadde made al this array
He sent his knaue and ek his wenche also
Vp on his nede to london for to go
And on the monday whan it drogh to nyght
He shette his dore with outen candil light
And dressith al thing as it shold bee
And shortly vp thei clomben al three
Thei setten stille wel a furlong way
Now pater noster clum seide Nicholay
And clum quod Iohn and clum seide Alison
This carpenter seide his deuosion
And stille he sit and biddith his pat̉er/re nostre
A waytyng on the reyn if he it here
The dede sleep for wery besinesse
Fil on this Carpent̉er/re right as I gesse
A boute corfu tyme orlitel more
For trauail f of his gost he groneth sore
And eft he routeh for his hed myslay
Doun of the laddre stalketh Nicholay
And Alisou ful softe a doun she spedde
With outen wordes mo thei gon to bedde
Ther as the Carpenter is wont to lye
Ther was the reuel and the melodye
An thus lyn Alisou and Nicholas
In besynesse of merthe and in solas
Til that the belle of laudes gan to renge
And freres in the chansell gon synge
This paryssh clerk this amerous Absolou
That is for loue alwey so wo bigou
Vp on the monday was at Osneye
With compaignye him to disporte and pleye
And axed vp on cas a cloistrere
Ful pryuely after Iohn the carpentere
And he drogh him a part out of the cherche
And seide y noot y saught him noght wirche
Sith saterday y trowe that he be went
For tymber ther as oure Abbot hath hem sent
For he is wont for tymber for to go
And dwellen at the gronge a day or two
Or elles he is at his hous certayn
Where that he be I kan noght soothly sayn
This Absolon ful Ioly was and light
And thoght now is tyme to wake al nyght
For sikerli I sagh hym noght styriynge
Aboute his dore seyn day bi gan to sprynge
So moot I thryue I shal at Cokkes crowe
Ful pryuely knokken at his wyndowe
That stant ful lowe vp on his boures wal
To Alison now wol I tellen al
Mi loue longyng for yit I shal nat mysse
That at the leest wey I shal hir kisse
Som maner comfort shal I haue parfay
Mi mouth hath ecched al this longe day
That is a signe of kissiyng at the leeste
Al nyght me met eek I was at a feste
Ther for y wol go slepe an houre or tweye
And al the nyght than wol I wake and pleie
Whan that the first kok hath crowe a non
Vp rist this Ioly louer Absolou
And hym arraieth gay and poynt deuyes
But first he cheweth greyns and licorys
To smellen swete er he had spoke with hire
Vnder his tonge a treweloue he beer
For ther by he went to be gracious
He rometh to the Carpenters hous
And stille he stont vnder his shop wyndowe
Vn to his breste it raughte it was so lowe
And soft he toughteth with a semy soun
What do ye hony combe swete Alisoun
Mi Fairebrid my swete synomome
A waketh lemman myn and speketh to me
Wel litel thynken ye vp on my wo
That for your loue I swete ther I go
No wonder es thogh that y swolt an swete
I moorne as doth a lambe after the tete
I wis lemman y haue swich loue longyng
That like a turtel trewe is my moornyng
I may ete nat ete namore than a mayde
Go fro the wyndowe Iacke fool she seyde
Has help me god it wol noght be come bame
I loue a nother or ellis y were to blame
Go forth thy wey or I wol caste a stou
And let me slep a twenty deuel wey
Allas quod absolou and weilawey
That trewloue was eủer/ree so euel biset
Thanne kys me syn thatt it may be no bet
For Ihu loue and for loue of me
Wolthow thanne go thy wey ther with quod she
Ye certes lemman quod this sory Absolou
Thanne make the redy quod she I come a non
This Absolon doun set him on his knees
And seide I am a lord at alle degrees
For after this I hope ther cometh moore
Lemman thi grace and swete brid thyn oore
The wyndowe she vndooth and that in haste
Haue doo quod she com of and speed the faste
Lest that oure neyghboures the espie
This Absolou gan wype his mouth ful drye
Derk was the nyght as pych or as the cole
And at the wyndowe out she putte hir hole
And Absolou hym fil no bet ne wers
But with his mouth he kissed hir naked ers
Ful sauourly er he was war of this
A bak he sterte and thoght hit was amys
For wel he wist a womman hath no berd
He felt a thyng alrough and longe y herd
And seid fi allas what haue I do
Tehe quod she and clapt the wyndowe to
An Absolou gooth forth a sory paas
A berd a berd seide hendy Nicholas
By goddes corpes this goth faire and wel
This sely Absolou herd eủer/rey del
And on his lippe he gan for angre bite
And to hym self he seid I shal the quyte
Who rubbeth now who freteth now his lippes
With dust with sond with straw with cloth with chippes
But Absolou that seith ful ofte allas
Mi soule bi take of vn to satanas
But me were leuer than al this toun quod he
Of this dispite a wroken for to be
Allas quod he allas I ne hadde y bleynt
His hote loue was colde and al I queynt
For fro that he hadde kyste hir ers
Of paramours he rought nat a kers
For he was heled of his malodie
Ful ofte ꝓproamours he gan defie
And wepp as doth a child that is bete
A softe paas he wente hym ouer the strete
Vn til a smyth men clepeth daun Gerues
That in his forge smethed plow hareieys
He sharpeth shaar and culter bisily
This Absolou knokketh al esily
And seide vndo Geruys and that a non
What who art thow it am I Absolou
What Absolou what cristes swete tree
Whi rise ye so rathe ey benedicitee
What eileth you som gay gerle god it woot
Had broght you thus vp on the viritoot
By seynt note ye woot wel what y mene
This absolou ne roght nat a bene
Of al this pleye no word a yeyn he yaf
He hadde moore taw on his distaf
Than Gerueys knew and seid frend so dere
That hote culter in the chymenee heere
As lene it me I haue ther with to doone
I wol brenge it the a gayn ful soone
Gerueys answered certes were it gold
Or in a poke nobles al vn told
Thow sholdyst haue as I am trewe smyth
Ey cristes foo what wol ye do ther with
Ther of quod absolou be as be may
I shal wel telle it the a nother day
And cauth the culter by the colde stele
Ful softe out at the dore he gan to stele
And wente vn to the carpenters wal
He cougheth first and knokketh ther with al
Vp on the wyndowe right as he deid er
This Alisou answered who is ther
That knokketh so I warant him it a theef
Nay nay quod he god woot my swete leef
I am thyn Absolou thi derelyng
Of gold quod he I haue the broght a ryng
Mi moder yaf it me so god me saue
Ful fyne is it and ther to wel y graue
This wol y yeuen the if thow me kysse
This Nicholas was risen vp to pisse
And thought he wolde a menden al the Iape
He shold kisse his ers er that he scape
And vp the wyndowe ded he in hast
And out hes ers he putteht pryuely
Ouer the buttok to the honche boon
¶ And ther with spake this clerk this Absolou
Speke swete brid I noot not where thow art
This Nicholas a non leet flee a fart
As gret as it hadde ben a thonder dent
That with the strook he was wel nygh y brent
And he was redy with his Iren hoot
And Nicholas in the ers he smot
Of gooth the skynne an hand brede a boute
The hote Culter brende so his towte
That for the smert he went for to daye
As he were wood for woo he gan crye
Help water water help for goddes hert
This Carpenter out of his slomber stert
And herd on crie water as he were wood
And thoght allas now cometh Noes flood
He sette him vp with oute wordes moo
And with his axe he smot the corde a too
And doun he goth ther he fonde neither to selle
Ne bred ne ale til he cam to the celle
Vp on the flore and ther aswowe he lay
Vp sterte hir Alisou and Nicholay
And criden out harrowe in the strete
The neghboures bothe smale and gret
In rannen for to gauren in this man
That as wod lay both pale and wan
For with the falle he brosten hadde his arm
But stonden he moste to his owene harm
For whan he was a non y bore a doun
With hendy Nycholas and with Alisou
Thei tolden eủer/rey man that he was wood
He was so a gast of Noeles flood
Thurgh fantesie that of his vanitee
He hadde yboght him knedyng tubbes thre
And hadde him honged in the roof a bowe
And that he prayed hem for goddes loue
Tho sitten in the roof ꝑper/par compenie
The folk gan laughen at his fantesie
In to the roof they kyken and thei capa
For what so that this Carpenter answerde
His was for noght no man his resou herde
With othes grete he was so sworn a dooun
He was holden wood in al the toun
For euery clerk a non right held with other
He seide the man was wood my leue brother
And eủer/rey wight gan laughen of this strif
Thus swyued was the Carpenters wif
For al his kepyng and his Ialowsie
Ad Absolou hath kyssed her nether eye
And Nicholas is schalded in the towte
This tale is don and god saue al the rowte

div.l: (base) As many a yeer / as it is passed henne

(base) ¶ Whan that oure hoost hadde herd this sermonyng

div.l: (base) ¶ Heere bigynneth / the Reues tale ~
(base) AT Trompyngtoun nat fer fro Cantebrygge

div.l: Prologus Prologuslegislegis pariti
HVre host saugh wel that the bright sonne
The ark of his Artificial day hath ronne
The ferth part and half an houre and moore
And though he were nat deep y stertein loore
He wist it was the eghteeighteeighte and twenty day
Of Aprill that is messager to May
And saught wel that the shadowe of eủer/rey tree
Was as in lyngth the same quantitee
That was the body erect that caused it
And therfore by the shadowe he took tookhishis wit
That phebus which that shoon so clere and bright
Degrees was fyue and forty clombe on hight
And for that day as in that latitude
It was ten of the clookke he gan conclude
And sodenly he plight his hors a boute
Lordynges quod he I warne you al the route
The ferth partye of this day is goon
Now for the loue of god and of seynt Iohn
Leseth no tyme as ferforth as ye may
Lordynges the tyme it wasteth bothe nyght and day
And steleth from vs what pryuely slepynge
And what thurg negelegence in oure wakynke
As dooth the streem that turneth neủer/ree a gayn
Discendyng from the montaigne in to playn
Wel can Senec and many a Plilosophre
By waillen tyme moore than gold in cofre
For les of catel may recouered be
But los of tyme shendeth vs quod he
It wol nat come a gayn with outen drede
Namore than wol Malkennes maidenhede
Whan she hath lost it in hir wantonesse
Lat vs nat mowlen thus in ydelnesse
Sire man of law quod he so haue ye blis
Tel vs a tale a non as forward is
Ye ben submytted thurgh youre free assent
To stonde in this cas at my Iugement
A quyteth you of youre bihest
Thanne haue ye doon youre deuoir atte leest
Hoost quod he dꝑper/pardieux ich assent
To breke forward is nat myn entent
Byhest is deette and y wol holde it fayn
Al my bihest I can no better sayn
For swich lawe as a man yeueth a nother wight
He sholde hym self vsen it by right
Thus wol owre text but natheles certeyn
I kan right now no thrifti tale seyn
That Chauser thogh he can but lewedely
On metres or on rimyng craftely
Hath seide hem in swich englissh as he kan
Of olde tyme as knoweth many a man
And if he haue noght seid hem leue brother
In o book he hath seid hem in a nother
For he hath told of loueris vp and doun
Mo than ouyde made mencioıı̄un
In hise epistoles that ben ful olde
What sholde I tellen hem seyn thei be tolde
In youthe he made of Ceys and alcione
And sethen hath he spoke of euerichone
Thise noble wyues and thise loueris eke
Who so that wole his large volume seke
Cleped the senetes legende of Cupide
Ther may he sen the large woundes wyde
Of lucresse and of Babilan Tesbe
The sword of dido for the false Eue
The tree of Phillis for hir demophon
The pleynte of siane and of hermyoıı̄un
Of Adriane and I Siphilee
The barayne Ile stondyng in the See
The dreynte leandre for his erro
The teeres of Eleyne and eke the wo
Of Brixeide and of the ladomia
The crewelte of the queene Medea
The litel children hangyng by the hals
For thi Iason that was of loue so fals
O ypmystra penalopee alceste
Your wifhode he comendeth with the beste
But certeinly no word ne writheth he
Of thilke ensample of Canocee
That louethlouedloueth loued hir owene brother synfuly
Of whiche cursed stories I sey fy
Or ellis of Tiro Appolonius
How that the cursed kyng Antiochus
By rafte his doughter of hir maidenhede
That is so horrible a tale for to rede
Whan he hir threwe vp on the pauement
And therfore he of s ful auysement
Nolde neủer/ree write in non of his sermons
Of swhich vnkynde abhomynacions
Ne y wole noon reherce if that y may
But of my tale hou shal I don this day
Me were loth be likned douteles
To Muses that men cleped Pierides
Methamorphosios woot what I mene
But nathelees I reeche noght a bene
Thogh I come after hym with ha we bake
I speke in prose and lat hym rymes make
And with that word he with a sobre chere
By gan his tale and said as ye shal after here
O hateful harme condicion of pouerte
With thurst with colde with honger so confoıı̄undit
To asken help the shameth in thin herte
If thow noon aske so soore artow y woıı̄undit
That varray nede vnwrappeth al thi woundehyd
Maugre thin hed thow most for indigense
Oþ̉er/re stele or begge or borwe thi dispense
Thow blamest crist and seiste ful bitterly
He mys deperteth richesse temꝑper/paral
Thi neghbor thow witest synfully
And seist thow hast to lite and he hath al
ꝐPer/Parfay seistow som tyme he rekene shal
Whan that is tail shal brennen in the gleede
For he noght helpeth nedfulle in hir nede
Herkene what is the sentence of the wise
Bet is to dyen than haue Indigencie
Thi selue neighbore wol thee dispise
If thow be poure farwel thi reuerence
Yit of the wise men tak this sentence
Alle the dayes of poure men ben wikke
Be war therfore er thow come to that prikke
If thow be poure thi brother hateth thee
And al thi frendes fleen from the allas
O riche Marchantz ful of wele ben yee
O noble o prudent folk as in this cas
Youre bagges ben noght filled with ambes as
But with sis synk that renneth for your chaunce
At cristemasse merye may ye daunce
Ye seken lond and see for youre wynnynges
As wyse folk ye knowen al the stat
Of regnes ye ben fadres of tydynges
And tales bothe of pees and of debat
I were right now of tales desolat
Nere that a Marchant goon is many a yeere
Me thaught a tale which that ye shal here
IN Surrye whilom dwelte a compaignie
Of chapmen riche and therto sadde and trewe
That wide where sende hir spicerie
Clothes of gold and satyns riche of hewe
Hir chaffare was so thrifty and so nwe
That euery wight hath deynte to chaffare
With hem and eke to sellen hem hir ware
Now fil it that the maistres of that sort
Haıı shapen hem to Rome for to wende
Were it for chapmanhode or for disport
Noon other messager wolde thei thider sende
But comen hem self to Rome this is thende
And in swich place as thoghte hem auantage
For hir entente thei taken hir herbergage
Soiourned haıı this Marchantz in that toun
A certein tyme as fil in hir plesance
And so bifil that thexcellent renoun
Of themꝑper/parours doughter dame Constance
Reported was with euery circumstance
Vn to this Surryen marchantz in swich wise
Fro day to day as y shal you deuyse
This was the comune vois of euery man
Our Emꝑper/parour of Rome god hym see
A doughter hath that syn the world bygan
To reken as wel hir goodnesse and beautee
Nas neủer/ree swich a nother as is shee
I pray god in honouur hir sustene
And wolde swhe were of Europe the queene
In here h is heigh beaute with outen pride
Youth with outen grenhed or folie
To al hir werkes v̉er/retue is hir gide
Humblesse hath slaen in hir tirannye
She is myrour of al curtesie
Hire herte is verry chambre of holinesse
Hir hond Mynestre of fredom for Almesse
And al this vois was soth as god is trewe
But now to pourpos lat vs now turne a gayn
This Marchantz haıı doon Fraught shipes newe
And whan thei haıı this blisful mayden sayn
Hoom to Surrye ben thei went ful fayn
And doon hire nedes as thei haıı doon yoore
And leuen in wele I can say you nomoore
Now fil it that thise Marchantz stode in gᵃce
Of hym that was the Sowdan of Surrye
For whan thei come fro any stronge place
He wold of his benyngne curteisie
Make hem good chere and besily espie
Tydynges of sondrey londes for to lere
The wondres that they myghte seen or here
A monges other thynges specially
Thise marchantz haıı hym tolde of dame Custance
So grete noblesse in ernest ceriously
That this Sowden hatht caught so gret plesance
To haıı hir figure in his remembrance
And al his lust and al his besi cure
Was for to loue hire while his lif may dure
ꝐPer/Parauenture in thilk large book
Which that men clepe the heuene I writen was
With sterres whan that he his burthe took
That he for loue shold haıı his deth allas
For in the sterres clerrer than is the glas
Is writen god woot who so koude it rede
The deth of eủer/rey man with outen drede
In sterres many a wynter ther byforn
Was writen the deth of Ector Achilles
Of pompey Iulyus er thei were born
The strif of Thebes and of Ercules
Of Sampson Turnes and of Socrates
The deth butte mennes wittes ben so dulle
That no wight kan wel rede it at the fulle
This sawdan for his pryue consel sent
And shortly of this matere for to passe
He hath to hym declared his entent
And saide hem c̉er/retein but he myght haue gᵃce
To haıı Custance with Inne a litel space
He nas but ded and charged hem in hye
To shapen for his lif som remedye
Dyủer/rese men dyủer/rese thynges seide
Thei argumentes casten vp and doun
Many a subtil resoıı̄un forth thei leide
Thei speken of Magik and Abusioıı̄un
But fynally as in conclusioıı̄un
Thei kan nat seen in that noon auantage
Ne in noon oother way saue mariage
Thei saw ther Inne swich difficultee
By weyes of reson for to speke al playn
By cause that ther was swich diủer/resitee
Bytwene hir both lawes that thei sayn
Thei trowe that no cristen prynce wold fayn
Wedden his child vnder oure lawes swete
That was yeuen by Mahoun oure ꝑper/parphete
And he answerd rather than I lese
Custance I wol be cristned doutelees
I moot ben hirs I may noon other chese
I pray youe hold youre argumentes in pees
Saueth my lif and beth nat recchelees
To geten hir that hath my lif in cure
For in this woo I may nat longe endure
What nedeth gretter dilatacioıı̄un
I say by tretys and ambassatrie
And by the popes mediacioıı̄un
And al the chirche and al the chyualrye
That in destruccioıı̄un of mawmetrie
And in encresse of cristes lawes deere
Thei ben a corded so as ye may here
How that the Sowdan and his Baronage
And alle his lieges sholde y cristned bee
And he shal haıı Custance in mariage
And sertein gold y noot what quantitee
And hir to fynde suffysant suretee
This same a corde was sworn in either side
Now fayre Custance al myghty god the gyde
Now wold som men waiten as y gesse
That y shold tellen al the purueiance
That Themꝑper/parour of his grette noblesse
Hath shapen for his doughter dame Custance
Wel may men knowen that so gret ordinance
May no man tellen in a litel clause
As was arrayed for so high a cause
Bisshopes ben shapen with hir to wende
Lordes ladyes knyghtes of renoun
And other folk y now this is thende
And notefied is thurgh out the toun
That eủer/rey wight with gret deuocioıı̄un
Shold prayen crist that he this mariage
Receyue in gree and spede this viage
The day is comen of hir dꝑper/partynge
I seye the woful day fatal is come
That there may be no lenger tariynge
But forth ward thei hem dressen alle and some
Custance that was with sorwe al oủer/recome
Ful pale a rist and dresseth hire to wende
For wel she seith ther nys noon oother ende
Allas what wonder is it thogh she wepte
That shal be sent to strounge nacioıı̄un
Fro Frendes that so tenderly hir kepte
And to be bounde vnder subieccioıı̄un
Of oon she knoweth nat his condicioıı̄un
Housboundes ben al goode and haıı ben yore
That knowen wyves I dar say namoore
Fader she seid thi wrecchid childe Custance
Thi yonge doghter fostred vp so softe
And ye my moder my soueryn plesance
Ouer alle thynge outtaken crist on lofte
Custance your childe hir recomande ofte
Vn to your grace for y shal to Surrye
Ne shal y neuere seen you more with yee
Allas vn to the Barbre nacioıı̄un
I moste goon syn that it is youre wille
But crist that straf for oure redempcioun
So yeue me grace his hestes to fulfille
I wrecche womman no fors thogh y spille
Womman ar born to thraldom and penance
And to ben vnder mannes gouernance
I trowe at Troye whan purreus brak the wal
Or whanne Ilioıı̄un brende Thebes the Citee
Nat Rome for the harme thurgh hanybal
That Romaynes hath venquyssed tymes three
Nas herd swich tendre wepyng for pytee
As in the chambre was for hir dꝑper/partyng
But forth she moot wher she wepe or syng
O first meuynge crwel firmament
With thi dyurnal sweygh that crowdest ay
And hurlest al fro Est til occident
That naturelly wold holde a nother way
Thi crowdynge set the heuene in swich array
That the begynnyng of this fiers viage
That cruel Mars hath slayn this mariage
Infortunat ascendent tortuous
Of which the lord is helplees falle allas
Oute of his angle in tho the derkest hous
O Mars o atyzar as in this cas
O Feble moone vnhappy ben thi paas
Thow kneyttest the ther thow nart nat receyued
Ther thow wer wel fro thennes artow weyued
Inprudent Emꝑper/parour of Rome allas
Was ther no Philisophre in al thi toun
Is no tyme bet than oother in swich cas
Of viage is ther noon eleccioun
Namely to folk of heigh condicioıı̄un
Nat whan a roote is of a burght y knowe
Allas we ben to lewed or to slowe
To shipe is broght this woful faire maide
SolemlSolempnlyeSolemlpnlye with eủer/rey circumstance
Now Ihu crist be with you alle she seide
Ther nys no moore but fare wel fayre Custance
She payneth hire to make good contenance
And forth y lat hir saille in this manere
And turne y wol a gayn to my matere
The modir of the Soudan welle of vices
Espied hath hir sones pleyn entente
How he wol lete his olde sacrifices
And right a noon she for hir counseil sente
And thei ben come to knowe what she mente
And whan assembled was this folk in feere
She sette hir doun and seide as ye shal heere
Lordes she seide ye knowen eủer/reychoun
How that my sone in poynt is for to lete
The holy lawes of oure Alkaroun
Yeuen by goddes messager Makamete
But on a vow to grete god I heete
The lif shal rather out of my body sterte
Than Makometes lawe out of myn hert
What sholde vs tyden of this newe lawe
But tharldom to oure bodyes and penance
And afterward in helle to be drawe
For we reneyed Mahoun oure creance
But lordes wol we maken assurance
As y shal sayn assentyng to my loore
And y shal maken vs saf for euermore
Thei sworen and assenten eủer/reychon
To lyue with hir and dye and by hir stonde
And eủer/reychen in the best wise he kan
To strengthen hire shal alle his frendes fonde

Come nere my spouse lat me ba thi cheke
Ye shold be al pacient and meke
And han a swete spiced concience
Sith ye so pche of Iopes pacience
Suffreth alwey syn ye so wel can pche
And but ye do c̉er/reteyn we shal you teche
That is faire to han a wif in pees
On of vs two most bowen doutelees
And sith a man is more resonable
Than woman is ye mosten ben suffrable
What eileth you to grocche thus and grone
It is for ye wolde haue y my queynte allone
Whi take it al lo haue it eueridel
Peter y swere srewe you but ye loue it wel
For if y wolde selle my bele chose
Y couthe walke as freessh as is a rose
But y wil kepe it for youre owen toth
Ye be to br blame by god y sey you soth
Suche man wordes had we in honde
Now wil y speke of my fierthe housbonde
Mi fierth housbonde was a reuelour
This to sayn he had a ꝑper/paramour
And I was yonge and ful of ragerie
Stiborne and stronge and ioly as a pye
How couthe I daıı̄unce to an harpe smale
And synge y wis as any ng nyghtyngale
Whan y had dronke a draught of swete wyn
Metellyus the foul cherle the swyn
That with a staf biraft his wif hir lif
For she drank wyn though y had ben his wif
Ne sholde nat a daunted me for drynke
And after wyn on venus most y thynke
For also siker as colde engendreth hayl
A likerous mouth most han a likerous tail
In a woman vynolent is no defence
This knowen lechours by exꝑper/parience
But lord crist whan it remembreth me
Vp on my youthe and on my iolitee
It tikelith me a boute myn herte rote
Vn to this day it doth myn herte bote
That y haue had my world as in my tyme
But age allas that al wol envenyme
Hath me byraft my beautee and my pith
Lat go farwel the deuel go ther with
The flour is goon ther is no more to telle
The bren as y best may now most y selle
But yit to be right meri wol y fonde
Now wil y telle of my fiefthe housbonde
I sey y had in herte gret dispite
That of any other had delite
But he was quyt by god and by seynt Ioce
I made hym of the same wode a croce
Nat of my body in no foul manere
But c̉er/reteynly y made folk suche chere
That in his owene grece y made hym frye
For anger and for verry Ialousye
By god inerthe y was his purgatorie
For whiche y hope his soule be in glorie
For god it woot he sat ful ofte and song
Whan that he is sho ful bitterly hym wrong
Ther was no wight saue god and he that wist
In many wise how sore y hym twyst
He deide whan y come fro Ierusalem
And lithe I graue vnder the rode beem
Al is his toumbe noght so cureous
As was the sepulture of hym daryus
Whiche that Appellus wrought so sotelly
It nys but wast to bury hem pciously
Lat hym farwel god geue his soule reste
He is now in is graue and in his cheste
Now of my fyfthe housbonde wol y telle
God let his soule neuer come in helle
And yit was he to me the most shrewe
That fele y on my ribbes al by rewe
And euer shal vn to myn endyng day
But in oure bedde he was so fressh and gay
And ther with also wel coude he me glose
Whan that he wolde han my bele chose
That though he hadde me bet on euery bon
He couth wynne a gayn my loue a non
I trowe y loued hym best for that he
Was of his loue doungerous vn to me
We woman han yif that y shal nat lye
In this manere a queyte fantasie
Wait what thyng we may nat lightili haue
Ther after wil we crie and craue
For bede vs thyng and that desiren we
Prees on vs fast and thanne wil we flee
With daunger oute we al oure chaffare
Gret prees at market maketh dere ware
And to gret chep is holden at litel pris
This knoweth eủer/rey woman that is wis
Mi fifthe housbonde god his saule blesse
Which that y took for loue and no richesse
He some tyme was a clerk of Oxenforde
And hadde laft scole and went at hoom at borde
With my gosseb dwellyng in oure toun
God haue hir soule hir name was Alisou
She knewe myn hert and ek my pryuetee
Bet than oure parissh preest as mot y thee
To hir bi wried y my conseil al
For had my housbonde pissed on a wal
Or don a thyng that shold haue cost his lif
To hir and to a nother worthi wif
And to my nece which that y loued wel
I wold han tolde his conseil eueridel
And so y dyd ful often god it wot
That made his face often red and hot
For verry shame and blamed hym self for he
Had told to me so gret a pryuetee
And so bifil that oones in a lente
So ofte tymes y to my gossib wente
For euer yit I loued to be gay
And for to walke in marche Aủer/reel and may
From housse to hous to here sondry tales
That Iankyn clerk and my gossib dame Alis
And y me self in to the feeldes went
Myn housbonde was at londou al that lent
I hadde the better leyser for to pleye
And for to see and ek for to be seye
Of lusty folk what wist y where my grace
Was shapen for to be or in what place
Ther fore y made my visitacions
To vigelees and to ꝓprocessioıı̄uns
To prechynges ekand to this pilgrymages
To pleyes of myracles and of mariages
And wered vp on my gay scarlet gytes
This wormes ne this moththes ne this mytes
Vp on my perel fert hem neuer adel
And wostow why for thei were vsed wel
Now wol y tellen forth what happed me
I sei that in the feeldes walked we
Til trewely we had such daliance
This clerk and y that of my purueance
I spak to hym and seide hym how that he
Yif y were wydowe sholde wedde me
For certeynly y say for no bobaunce
Yit was y neuer with outen purueance
Of mariage ne of other thynges eke
I holde a mouses herte nought worth aleke
That hath but on hole for to sterte to
And yf that faile thanne is al y do
But now sire lat me se what shal y seyn
Aha by god I haue my tale a gayn
Whan that my fourthe housbonde was a bere
I wepe algate and made sore chere
As wyues moten for it is vsage
And with my couerchief coủer/reed my visage
But for that y was pʳuey of a make
I wept but smal and that y vndertake
To cherche was myn housbonde born a morwe
With neighbours that for hym maden sorwe
And Iankyn oure clerk was oon of tho
As help me god whan that y saw hym go
After the bere me thoughte he hadde a payre
Of legges and feet so clene and so fayre
That al myn hert I yaue vn to his holde
He was y trowe twenty wynter olde
And y was fourty if y shal sey soth
But yit y had al wey a coltes toth
Gat tothed y was and that bi came me wel
I had the preente of venus sel
As help me god y was a lustion
And faire an righe and yonge and wel bigon
And trewly as myn housbondes tolden me
I had the best quonyam that myght be
Myn assendent was taur and Mars ther Inne
Allas allas that euer loue was synne
I folowed ay myn inclynaciou
By vertu of my constellaciou
That made me that y couth nat withdrawe
My chamber of Venus from a god felawe
What sholde y sey but at the monthes ende
This Ioly clerk Iankyn that was so hende
Hath wedded me with gret solempnitee
And to hym yaf y al my londe and fee
That euer was me yeuen therbyfore
But after ward repented me ful sore
He nolde suffre no thyng of my list
Bi god he smote me ones on the list
For that y rente out of his boke a leef
That of the stroke myn ere wax al deef
Stiborne y was as is a leonesse
And of my tonge a verry Iangleresse
And walke y wolde as y had doon by forn
From hous to hous al though he had it sworn
For whiche he often tymes wolde preche
And me olde Romayne gestes teche
How he symplycius Gallus lefte his wif
And hir for soke for terme of al his lif
Noght but for open heueded he hir say
Lokyng out at is dore vp on aday
An other Romayne tolde he me by name
That for his wif was at a someres game
With outen his wetyng he forsoke hir eke
And thanne wolde he vpon his bible seke
That ilke ꝓprouerbe of Ecclesiaste
Where he comaundeth and forbedeth faste
Man shal nat suffren his wif go roille a boute
Thanne wolde he sey right thus with outen doute
Who so that bildeth his hous al of salwes
And priketh his blynde hors ouer the falwes
And suffreth his wif to go seken halwes
Is worthi to be honged on the galwes
But al for nought y set nat an hawe
Of his ꝓprouerbes ne of his olde sawe
Ne y ne wolde nat of hym corrected be
I hate hem that my vices tellen me
And so do moo god woot of vs than I
This made hym with me woode al outerly
I nolde nat forbere hym in no cas
Now wil y sey you soth by seynt Thomas
Whi that y rente out of his book a leef
For which he smote me so that y was deef
He had a book that gladly nyght and day
For his disporte he wolde rede alway
He cleped it valerie and theofraste
At whiche book he low al way ful faste
And eke ther was som tyme a clerk at Rome
A cardynal that hight Seynt Ierome
That made a book a gayn Iouynyan
In which book eke ther was Thertulan
Crisispus Trotula and Helowes
That was Abbesse nought fer fro parys
And eke the ꝑper/parables of Salamon
Ouydes art and bokes many oon
And alle thise were bonden in o volume
And eủer/rey nyght and day was his Custume
Whan he had leiser and vacacioun
From other worldly ocupacion
To reden in this book wikked wyues
He knewe of hem moo legendes and lyues
Than ben of good wyues in the byble
For trusteth wel it is an in possible
That any clerk wil speke good of wyues
But if it be of holy seyntes lyues
Nof noon other wōmmen neuer the mo
Who peynted the leon telle me who
By god yf wymmen had writen stories
As clerkes han with In hir oratories
Thei wolde haue writen of men more wikkednesse
Than al the merke of adam may redresse
The children of mercury and venus
Ben in hir werkyng ful contrarious
Mercury loueth wisdome and science
And venus loueth riot and dispence
And for hir dyuers disposiciou
Eche faileth in otheres Exaltaciou
As thus god wot Mecurie is dosolat
In pisses where venus is exaltat
And venus faileth where Mercureus is reised
Therfor no woman of no clerk is preised
The clerk whan he is olde and may noght do
Of venus werkes nat worth his olde sho
Thanne sit he doun and writeth in his dotage
That wōmmen can nat kepe hir mariage
But now to pʳpos whi y tolde the
That y was beten for a book ꝑper/parde
Vp on a nyght Iankyn that was oure sire
Red on his book as he sat by the fyre
Of Eua frist that for hir wekkednesse
Was l al man kynde brought to wrecchednesse
Tho redde he me how Sampsou lost his heres
Slepyng his lemman kit it with hir sheres
Thourgh which tresou lost he both his eyen
Tho redde he me if that y shal nat lyen
Of hercules and of his dyanyre
That caused hym to sette hym self a fire
No thyng for gat he care and wo
That Socrates had with his wyues two
How exantipa caste pisse vp on his hed
This sely man sat stille as he were ded
He wipt his hed nomore dorst he seyn
But or that thondre stynt comth a reyn
Of phasipha that was the quyn of grece
For shrewednesse hym thought the tale swete
Fy speke no more it is a grisly thyng
Of orrible lust and hir likyng
Of clitermystra for hir lecherie
That falsly made hir housbonde for to dye
He redde it with ful good deuociou
He tolde me eke for what occasiou
Amphiorax at thebes lost his lif
Myn housbonde had a legende of his wif
Exiphilem that for an nouche of gold
Hath pryuely vn to the Grekes told
Where that hir housbonde hidde hym in a place
For which he had at thebes sory grace
Of lyuia tolde he me and of lucie
They both made hir housbondes for to dye
That on for loue that other was for hate
Lyuia hir housbonde on an euen late
Empisoned hath for that she was his fo
Lycia lykerous loued hir housbond so
That for he shulde al wey vp on hir thynke
She yaue hym such a maner loue drynke
That he was ded or it was bi the morwe
And thus algatis housbondes hadden sorwe
Thanne tolde me how oon lathumeus
Compleyned vn to his felawe Arrius
Right sore abasshed and dismayed
And in this wise sothely he sayd
That in his gardyne growed suche a tree
On which he seyde how that his wyues three
Honged hem self for hertes dispitous
O leue brother quod this Arryus
Yif me a plante of thilke blessed tree
And in my gardyn planted shal it be
Of later date of wyues hath he redde
Than some han slayn hir housbondes in hir bedde
And lat hir lechour dight hir al the nyght
Whil that the corps lay in the flore vpright
And some han dryuen nayles in hir brayn
Whil that they sleep and thus they han hem slayn
Some han hem yeuen poisou in hir drynke
He spake more harme thanne herte may bethynke
And ther with al he knew mo ꝓprouerbes
Than in this world ther growen grase or herbes
Bet is quod he thyn habitaciou
Be with a lyou or a foul dragou
Than with a woman vsyng for to chide
Bet is quod he heigh in the roof a byde
Than with a wikked woman doun in the hous
Thei ben so wikked and contᵃrious
Thei haten that hir housbondes loueth ay
He seide a woman cast hir shame a weye
Whan she kast of hir smokke and forthermo
A fayre woman but if she be chaste also
Is like a goldryng in a sowes nose
Who wolde wene or wolde suppose
The wo that in myn hert was and pyne
And whan I sey he nolde neuer fyne
To reden on this cursed book al nyght
Alsodeynly thre leues haue I plight
Out of his book right as he red and eke
I with my fyst so toke hym on the cheke
That in oure fire he fil bak ward a doun
And he vpstert as doth a wood leoun
And with his fist he smote me on the hed
That in the flore y lay as y were ded
And whan he saugh how stille that y lay
He was a gast and wolde a fled away
Til atte laste out of my swough y brayde
O hastow slayn me fals theef y seyde
And for my land thus hastow mortherd me
Or y be ded yit wole y kisse the
And nerre he come and kneled faire a doun
And seide dere suster Alisoun
As help me god y shal the neuer smyte
That y haue doon it is thi self to wyte
For yeue it me and that y the biseke
And yit eft sones y hitte hym on the cheke
And seide theef thus moche y me wreke
Now wil y dye y may no lenger speke
But atte laste with mochel care and wo
We fel accorded by oure seluen two
He yaf me al the bridel in myn honde
To han the goủer/renance of hous and lande
And of his tonge and of his honde also
And made hym brenne his book a non right tho
And whan that y had geten vn to me
By maistrie al the soủer/reeygntee
And that he seide myn owen trewe wif
Do as the lust the t̉er/reme of al thi lif
Kepe thyn honoᵘur and kepe myn estate
After that day we had neuer debate
God help me so y was to hem as kynde
As any wif fro denmark vn to ynde
And also trewe and so was he to me
I pray to god that sitte on maieste
So blesse his saule for his mercy dere
Now wil y sey my tale yf ye wil here
The frere lough whan he had herd al this
¶ Now dame quod he so haue y ioy or blis
This is alonge pamble of a tale
And whan the Soumnoᵘur herde the frere gale
Lo quod the Sumnoᵘur goddes Armes two
A frere wil entermete hym euer mo
Lo good men a fleye and eke a frere
Wil falle in eủer/rey dissh and matere
What spekestow of pambulaciou
What aumble or trotte or pees or go sit doun
Thow lettest oure disport in this manere
Ye wiltow so sire Soumnoᵘur quod the frere
Now by my fayth y shal or that y go
Telle of a sumnoᵘur such a tale or two
That al the folke shal laughen in this place
Now elles frere y wil bishrewe thi face
Quod this Sumnoᵘur and y be bishrewe me
But y telle tales two or three
Of freres or y come to Sydenbourne
That y shal make thyn hert to morne
For wel y wot thi pacience is goon
Oure host cried pees and that a non
And seide lat the woman telle hir tale
Ye fare as folk that dronken ben of ale
Do dame telle forth youre tale and that is best
Al redy sire quod she right as you lest
Yif y haue licence of this worthi frere
Yis dame quod he telle forth and y wol here
(base) Here bigynneth the tale of the Wyf of Bathe

(base) Of which that Britons speken greet honour

(base) The Elf queene with hir ioly compaignye
(base) Daunced ful ofte in many a grene mede

(base) As thikke as any motis in the sonne beme
