div.l: (base) Thropes Bernes Shipnes Dayeryes
(base) This maketh that ther been no fairyes
(base) For ther as wont to walken was an Elf
(base) Ther walketh now the lymytour hymself
(base) In vndermelys and in morwenynges
(base) And seith his matyns and his holy thynges
(base) As he gooth in his lymytacioun
(base) Wommen may go saufly vp and down
(base) In euery bussh or vnder euery tree
(base) Ther is noon oother Incubus but he
(base) And he ne wol doon hem but dishonour
(base) And so bifel that this kyng Arthour
(base) Hadde in his hous a lusty Bachiler
(base) That on a day cam ridyng fro Ryuer
(base) And happed that allone as he was born
(base) He say a mayde walkynge hym biforn
(base) Of which mayde anoon maugree hir hed
(base) By verray force he rafte hir maydenhed
(base) For which oppressioun was swich clamour
(base) And swich pursuyte vnto the kyng Arthour
(base) That dampned was this knyght for to be deed
(base) By cours of lawe and sholde han lost his heed
(base) Par auenture swich was the Statut tho
(base) But that the queene and othere ladyes mo
(base) So longe preyden the kyng of grace
(base) Til he his lyf hym graunted in the place
(base) And yaf hym to the queene al at hir wille
(base) To chese wheither she wolde hym saue or spille
(base) The queen thanked þe kyng wiþ al hir might
(base) And after this thus spak she to the knyght
(base) Whan that she saw hir tyme vpon a day
(base) Thow standest yet quod she in swich array
(base) That of thy lyf yet hastow no suretee
(base) I graunte thee lyf if thow kanst tellen me

div.l: (base) What thyng is it that wommen moost desiren
(base) Be war and keep thy nekke boon from Iren
(base) And if thow kanst nat tellen me anon
(base) Yet wol I yeue thee leue for to gon
(base) A twelf monthe and a day to seche and lere
(base) An answere suffisant in this matere
(base) And seuretee wol I han er that thow pace
(base) Thy body for to yelden in this place
(base) Wo was this knyght and sorwefully he siketh
(base) But what he may nat doon al as hym liketh
(base) And atte laste he chees hym for to wende
(base) And come agayn right at the yeres ende
(base) With swich answere as god wolde hym purueye
(base) And taketh his leue and wendeth forth his weye
(base) He seketh euery hous and euery place
(base) Where as he hopeth for to fynde grace
(base) To lerne what thyng wommen loue moost
(base) But he ne koude arryuen in no coost
(base) Where as he myghte fynde in this matere
(base) Two creatures acordyng in feere
(base) Somme seyden wommen louen best richesse
(base) Somme seyde honour somme seyde Iolifnesse
(base) Somme riche array somme lust abedde
(base) And ofte tyme to be widwe and wedde
(base) Somme seyde that oure herte is moost esed
(base) Whan that we been yflatered and yplesed
(base) He gooth ful ny the sothe I wol nat lye
(base) A man shal wynne vs best with flaterye
(base) And with attendaunce and with bisynesse
(base) Been we ylymed bothe moore and lesse
(base) And somme seyn that we louen best
(base) For to be free and do right as vs lest
(base) And that no man repreue vs of oure vice
(base) But seye that we be wise and no thyng nyce

div.l: (base) And clepe hym fader for youre gentilesse
(base) And Auctours shal I fynden as I gesse
(base) Now ther ye seye that I am foul and old
(base) Thanne drede yow noght to been a Cokewold
(base) For filthe and elde also mote I thee
(base) Been grete wardeyns vpon chastitee
(base) But nathelees syn I knowe youre delit
(base) I shal fulfille youre worldly appetit
(base) Chees now quod she oon of thise thynges tweye
(base) To han me foul and old til that I deye
(base) And be to yow a trewe humble wyf
(base) And neuere yow displese in al my lyf
(base) Or ellis ye wol han me yong and fair
(base) And take youre auenture of the repair
(base) That shal be to youre hous by cause of me
(base) Or in som oother place may wel be
(base) Now chees your seluen wheither that yow liketh
(base) This knyght auyseth hym and soore siketh
(base) But atte laste he seyde in this manere
(base) My lady and my loue and wyf so deere
(base) I putte me in youre wise gouernaunce
(base) Cheseth youre self which that may be moost plesaunce
(base) And moost honour to yow and me also
(base) I do no fors the wheither of the two
(base) For as yow liketh it suffiseth me
(base) Thanne haue I gete of yow maistrye quod she
(base) Syn I may chese and gouerne as me lest
(base) Ye certes wyf quod he I holde it best
(base) Kys me quod she we be no lenger wrothe
(base) For by my trouthe I wol be to yow bothe
(base) This is to seyn ye bothe fair and good
(base) I pray to god that I mote steruen wood
(base) But I to yow be also good and trewe
(base) As euere was wyf syn that the world was newe

div.l: (base) And but I be to morn as fair to sene
(base) As any lady Emperice or Queene
(base) That is bitwix the Est and eek the West
(base) Do with my lyf and deth right as yow lest
(base) And so they slepte tyl it was morow gray
(base) And then she sayd when it was day
(base) Cast vp the Curtyn looke how that it is
(base) And whan the knyght say verraily al this
(base) That she so fair was and so yong ther to
(base) For ioye he hente hire in his armes two
(base) His herte bathed in a bath of blisse
(base) A thousand tyme a rewe he gan hir kisse
(base) And she obeyed hym in euery thyng
(base) That myghte do hym plesance or likyng
(base) And thus they lyue vnto hir lyues ende
(base) In parfit ioye and Ihu crist vs sende
(base) Housbondes meke yonge and fressh a bedde
(base) And grace touerbyde hem that we wedde
(base) And eek I praye Ihu shorte hir lyues
(base) That noght wol be gouerned by hir wyues
(base) And olde and angry nygardes of dispence

div.l: Sire clerk of Oxenford oure Hoost sayde
Ye ride as coy and stille as dooth a mayde
Were newe spoused sittyng at the bord
This day ne herde I of your tonge a word
I trowe ye studie aboute som Sophyme
But Salomon seith euery thyng hath tyme
For goddes sake as beth of bettre cheere
It is no tyme for to studien heere
Tel vs som murie tale by youre fey
For what man that is entred in a pley
He nedes moot vn to the pley assente
But precheth nat as freres doon in lente
To maken vs for oure olde synnes wepe
Ne that thy tale make vs nat to slepe
Tel vs som murye thyng of auentures
Youre termes your colours and your figures
Kepe hem in stoor til so be ye endite
Heigh stile as whan that men to kynges write
Speketh so pleyn at this tyme we yow preye
That we may vnderstonde what ye seye
This worthy clerk benygnely answerde
Hoost quod he I am vnder your yerde
Ye han of vs as now the gouernaunce
And therfore wol I do yow obeisaunce
As fer as reson asketh hardily
I wol yow telle a tale which that I
Lerned at Padwe of a worthy Clerk
As proued by his wordes and his werk
He is now deed and nayled in his Cheste
I pray to god so yeue his soule reste
Fraunceys Petrak the lauryat poete
Highte this clerk whos Rethoryk swete
Enlumyned al Ytaille of Poetrie
As Lynyan dide of Philosophie
Or lawe or other art ꝑper/particuler
But deth that wole nat suffre vs dwelle here
But as it were twynclyng of an eye
He bothe hath slayn and and all shyl we deye
But for to tellen of this worthi man
That taught me this tale as y began
I sey that fyst he with hie stile enditith
Or he the body of his tale writeth
A prohemye in the which descreuyth he
Pemond and of Saluces the countre
And speketh of appenyn the hillehilleshilleshye
That ben the boundes of Westlumbardye
And of mont Vesules in speciall
Where as the poo out of a wel small
Taketh his first sprynginge and his cours
That estward ay encheset in his cours
To Emele ward to Ferare and Venyse
The wheche a long thyng were to deuyse
And trewely as to my iugement
Me thynketh it a thyng inꝑper/partinent
Sauf that he wole conueyen his matere
But this is the tale whiche that ye may here
The Clarke of Oxenforde tale
t heer is right at þe Westside of ytaille
Douwn atte rote of Vesulus the colde
A lusti pleyn haboundant of Vitaille
Ther many a toun and tour thow mayst biholde
That founded were in tyme of fadres olde
And many an other deitable sighte
And Saluces this noble contre highte
A markes whilom lord was of that lond
As were his worthi eldres hym byfore
And obeisant ay redy to his hond
Were alle his lieges both lasse and more
Thus in delit he leueth and hath doon yore
By loued and drad thurgh Fortune
Bothe of his lordes and of his comune
Ther with he was to speken of lynage
The gentillest y born of lymbardie
A fair ꝑper/parsone and strong and yong of age
And ful of honour and of curtesye
Discret y now his countre for to gide
Sauf in sum thynges that he was to blame
And Wauter was this yonge lordes name
I blame hym thus that he considerith nought
In tyme comyng what myght hym be tyde
But on hys lust present was al his thoght
As for to hauke and hunte on eủer/rey side
Wel ny al other cures let he slide
And eke he nolde and that was werst of alle
Wedde no wif for ought that may befalle
Only that poynt his peple bidbarbidarso sore
That flokmel on a day to hym they wente
And on of hem that wisest was of lore
Or elles that the lord wolde best assente
That he shulde telle hym what the peple mente
Or elles coude he shewe wel swich matere
He to the Marquys seyde as ye shul here
O noble Marquys youre humanite
Assureth vs and yeue vs hardinesse
As ofte as tyme of necessitee
That we you may telle our heuynesse
Acceptith lord thanne of youre gentillesse
That we with pitous herte vn to you pleyne

Al haue y not do do⁊andabsent: do to do in this matere

And ye my lord to do right as you leste

And al youre werk and euer han doon that we
Ne coude nat oure self deuysen how

Ay fleeth the tyme it wol no man abide
And though youre grene youthe floure as yit
In crepeth age alwey as stille as ston

Acceptith⁊andabsent:AcceptithBen of that day deth shal vn vs falle

That neuer yit refuseden youre heste
And ⁊andabsent:wewewol lord yf that ye wele assente

Honour to god and you as we can deme
Delyuere vs ⁊andabsent:outeouteof this besy drede

That thurgh youre deth youre lynage shuld slake
And that a straunge successour shulde take
Youre heritage o wo were vs alyue
Wher for we pray you hastyly to wyue
Hir meke prayere and her pitous chere

To that y neuere er thoghte streyne me

That selden tyme is funden in mariage

And truste vp on youre wit and haue doon ay
Wherfore of my fre wille y wole assente
To wedde me as sone as euere y may
But there as ye han profered me to day
To chese me a wif y you relese

For god it wot that children often ben
Vnlyk hir worthi eldres hem before

I trwstein goddes bountee and ther fore
Mi mariage and myn estate and reste
I hym betake he may do as hym liste
Lat me allone in chesyng of my wif
That charge vpon my bak y wole endure
But y you preye and charge vp on youre lif
That what wif y take that ye massure
To worsshipe hir whil that hir lif may dure
In word werk bothe here and eủer/rey where
As she emꝑper/paroures doughter were
And furthermore this shul ye swere that ye

div.l: I prey/you speke no more of this matere
With hertly wille they sworen and assenten
To al this thyng there seyde no wight nay
Bysekyng hym of grace or that they wenten
That he wolde graunten hem a c̉er/reteyn day
Of his spousaile as sone as euer he may
For yit al way the peple sum what dredde
Lest that the marquys no wif wold wedde
He graunted hem a day swich as hym leste
On whiche he wolde be wedded sikerly
And seid he did al this at hir requeste
And thei with humble entent ful buxumly
Knelyng vp on hir knees ful reuerently
Hym thanken alle and thus they han an ende
Of hir entent and hom agayn they wente
And here vp on he to his officers
Commaundith for the feste to purueye
And to his pryue knyghtes and squyers
Swiche charge yaf as hym list on hem leye
And they to his commandement obeye
And eche of hem dooth al his diligence
to do vn to the feste a reuerence
¶ pars fabule chiīm
nOught fer from thilke paleys honurable
Where as this marquys shoop his mariage
Ther stod a thorp of site delitable
In the which that pore folk of that vilage
Hadden hir bestes and hir herbergage
And of hir labour took hir sustenaunce
After the erthe yaf hem habundaunce
Among this pore folk ther dwelt a man
Whiche that was holden porest of hem alle
But hye god sum tyme sende can
His grace in to a litel oxes stalle
Ianicola men of that troop hym calle
A dowter hadde he fair ynow to sighte
And Grysildis this yonge mayde highte
But for speke of vertuous beaute
Thanne was she the fayreste vnder sonne
Ful pouerly yfostred vp was she
No likerous lust was in hir herte y ronne
Wel ofter the⁊andabsent:theof the welle than the toune Wel ofter of the welle than of the tonne
She drank and for she wolde vertu plese
She knew wel labour but non idel ese
But though this maide tendre were of age
Yit in the brest of hir virginitee
There was enclosed ripriperipeand sad corage
And in gret reuerence and charitee
Hir olde pore fader fostryd she
A fewe shep spynnyng on feeld she kepte
She wolde nat be ydel til she slepte
And whan she homward came she wolde brynge
Wortes or other erbes tymes ofte
The whiche she shredde and seth for hir lynynge
And made her bed ful hard and nothyng softe
And ay she kepte hir fadres lif on lofte
And forth ge goth with a ful sobre chere
Out atte dore and after that cam she
And to the peple he seyde in this manere
This is my wif quod he that stondeth here
Honoureth here and loueth here y preye
Ho so me loueth ther nys no more to seye
And for that no thyng of here olde gere
She shulde brynge in to his hous he bad
That wommewommenwommenshulde dispoilen hir right there
Of whiche this ladies weren no thyng glad
To handel hir clothes where in she was clad
But natheles this mayden bright of hewe
Fro foot to heed they clothed hadde al newe
Hir heres han they kempt that lay vntressed
Ful rudely and with hir fyngres smale
A corone on here hed they han ydressed
And sette it ful of nouches grete and smale
Of hir array what shulde y make a tale
Vnnethe the peple hir knewe for hir fairnesse
Whan she transmewyd was in swich richesse
This marquys hath hir spoused with a ryng
Brought for the same cause and than hir sette
Vp on an hors snow whit and wel anmblynge
And to his palys or he lengere lette
With ioyful peple that hir ladde and mette
Conueyed here and thus the day they spende
In reuel thil the sonne gaan descende
And shortly forth this matere for to chace
I sey to this new Marquysesse
Fod hath swiche fauour sent here of his grace
That it semeth nat by liklynesse
That she was born and fed in rudenesse
As in a cote or in oxe stalle
But norisshed in an Emꝑper/parours halle
To euery wight she waxen is do dere
And worsshipful that folk there she was bore
And from hir birthe knew hir yeer be yeer
Vnneth trowed they but durst han swore
That to Ianycle of whiche y spake before
She doughtir ne was for as be coniecture
Hem d⁊andabsent:dthought she was a nother creature
For thogh that euere vertuous was she
She was encresed in swich excellence
Of thewes goode y set in hy bountee
And so discret and fair of eloquence
So benygne and so dygne of reuerence
And cowde so the peples herte enbrace
That eche hir loueth that loketh on hir face
Nat only of Saluces in the toun
Puplisshed was the bountee of hir name
But eke be side in many a region
if on seith wel a nother seith the same
So spredeth of hir hy bounte the fame
That men and wommen as wel yonge as olde
Gon to Saluce vp on hir to biholde
Thus Wauter lowely nay but really
Wedded with forunat honestitee
In goddes pees lyuyth ful esyly
At home and grace outward y now hadde he
And for he saw that vnder lowe degree
Was ofte vertu hid the peple hym held
A prudent man and that is seen ful seld
Nat only this Grisildis thurgh hir wit
Coude al the feet of wifly homlynesse
But ek whan the cas requyred it
The comune ꝓprofit coude she redresse
The nas discord rancour ne heuynesse
In al that land that she ne couth appese
And wisly brynge hem alle in herte ese
Thogh that hir housbond absent were or noon
If gentil men or other of hir countree
Were wrothe she wold brynge hem at on
So wise and ripe wordes hadde she
And Iuggement of so gret equitee
That she from heuene sent was as men wende
Peple to saue and euery wrong to amende
Nat longe tyme after that this Grisild
Was wedde she a doghter hath ybore
Al hadde hir leuer han born a knaue childe
Glad was the Marquys and his folk therfore
For thought a mayden child come al before
She may y vn to a knaue child ateyne
By liklyhed syn she nys nat bareyne
¶ I pars bavule cliām
Ther fil as it be fallith tymes moo
Whan that this child had soukyd but a throwe
This Marquys in his herte longeth soo
To tempe his wif hir sadnesse for to knowe
That he myghte out of his herte throwe
This merueylous desyse his wif tassayee
Nedles god wot he thoght hir for taffraye
He hadde assaied hir y now before
And fond here euere good what nedeth it
Hir for to tempte and alwey mo and more
But as for me y sey that euele it sit
Thou some men preyse it for a sotil wit
Tassaye a wif whan that it is no nede
And putten here in angwissh and in drede
Fro which this Marquys wroghte in this manere
He cam a nyght allone there she lay
With steerne face and with ful trouble chere
And seid thus Griseld quod he that day
That y you took out of youre pore array
And put you in estate in hy noblesse
Ye han it nat forgeten as y gesse
I sey Grisild this present dignitee
In which e that y haue put you as y trowe
Maketh you nat forgetful for to bee
That y you took in poore estat ful lowe
For ony whele yyeyemot youre seluen knowe
Tak heed of euery word that y seye
Ther nys no wight that hereth it but we tweye
Ye wot youre self wel how that ye cam heere
In to this hous it is not longe agoo
And thogh to me ye be right leef and dere
Vn to my gentelys ye be no thyng so
Thei sey to hem it is gret shame and wo
For to be suggetes and ben in seriage
To the that born artof a smal vilage
And namely syn thi doghtir was ybore
This worde han thei spoken doutelees
But y desire as y haue doon before
To lyue my lif with hem in reste and pees
I may nat in this cas be rechelees
I mot do/whit thi doughter for the beste
Nat as y wolde but as my gentils leste
And yit god wote this is ful lothe to me
But natheless with outen youre wytyng
I wol ⁊andabsent:notnotdo but thus wole y quod he
That ye to me assenten in this thyng
Shewe now your pacience in your wirkyng
That me⁊andabsent:meye me hight and swere in yone vilage
The day that makid was oure mariage
Whan she had herd al this she nath amened
Nowthir in word chere ne contenaunce
For as hit semed she was nat agreeued
She seid lord al lyth in youre plesaunce
Mi child an y with hertly obeisaunce
Ben youres and ye mow saue and spille
Youre owne thyng werkith after your wille
Ther may ne thyng so god my sowle saue
Lyke vn to you that myght displese me
Ne y desire no thyng for to haue
Ne dreed for to leese sauf only ye
This wille is in myn herte and ay shal bee
No lengh of tyme or deth may this deface
ne chaunge my corage to an othir place
Glad was this Marquys for hir answerenge
But yit he feyned as he were not soo
Al drey was his cheere and his lokynge
Whan that he shulde out of the chambre goo
Sone aftir this a forlong wey or two
He pryuely hath told al his enteent
Vn to a man and to his wif hym sente
A maner sergeant was this pryue man
The which he feithful often founden hadde
In thyngethyngesthyngesgrete and eke swich folk wel can
Dooo execucion on thynges badde
the lord knew wel that he hym loued and dradde
And whan this sergeant knew his lordes wille
Out of the chambre he stalkitly hym ful stille
Madame he seide ye mot foryeue it me
Thogh y do a thyng to which y am constreyned
Ye ben so wis that right wel knowen ye
That lordes heestes mow nat be feyned
They mow wel be bywayled and compleyned
But men mot nedeles to hir lust obeye
And so wol y ther nys no more to seye
This child am y commaunded for to take
And spak nomore but out the child he hente
Despitously and gan a cheere make
Right as he wolde han slayn it or he wente
Grisildis mot al soffre and al concente
And as a lamb she sittith meke and stille
And let this cruel sergeant haue his wille
Suspecious was the deffame of this man
Suspect his face suspect his word also
Suspectthe tyme in whiche he this began
Allas hir doghtir that she loued so
She wende he wolde han slayn it right so
But natheles she neyther wepte ne sikyd
Conformyng hir to that the Markis lykyd
But at laste speke she began
And mekely to the Sergeant preyde
So as he was a worthi gentil man
The she muste kysse hir child or that it deide
And in hir barm this litel child she leyde
With ful sad face and gan the child to blisse
And lullyd it and after gan it kysse
And thus she seide in hir benygne voys
Far wel my child y shal the neuere se
But syn y the haue markyd with the croys
Of thilk fader blessed mot he be
That for vs deyde vp on a croys of tre
Thi soule litil child y hym bytake
For this myght shaltow deyen for my sake
Y trowe to a norice in this cas
It had ben hard thus ruth for to see
We myght a modir than han crid allas
But nathelees so sad stedfast was she
That she endured al aduersitee
And to the sergeant mekely she sayde
Haue hir agayn your litel yonge mayde
Goth now quod she and doth my lordes heste
But o thyng wolde y prey you of youre grace
That but my lord forbad you at leste
Burieth this litel body in sum place
That bestes ne no briddes it to race
But he no word wolde to the purpos seye
But took the child and went vp on his wey
This sergeant cam vn to his lord agayn
And of Grisildes wordes and hir cheere
He tolde hym poynt for poynt in short and pley
And hym presentid with his doghter deere
Sum what this lord hath ruth in hir manere
But nathelees his purpos held he stille
As lordes dos whan they wol haue hir wille
And bad this sergeant that he pryuely
Shuld this child ful softe wynde and wrappe
With al circumstaunces tendrely
And cary it in a cofre or in a lappe
But vpon peyne his heed of for to swappe
That no man shulde of this entente
Ne when he cam ne whidir that he wente
But at Boloigne it to his suster deere
That thilke tyme of pauyk was countesse
He shuld it take and shewe hir this matere
Besekyng hir to do hir bisynesse
This child to fostren in al gentillesse
And whos child that it was he bad hir hide
From euery wight for aght that may be tyde
This sergeant goth and hath fulfilde this thyng
But to the marquys now retorne we
For now goth he ful ofte ymagynyng
If by his wyues cheere he myghte see
Or by her word apperceyne that she
Were chaungid but he neuer coude hir fynde
But euer in on ylike sad and kynde
As glad as humble as besy in seruise
And ek in loue as she was wont to be
Was she to hym in eủer/rey maner wife
Ne of hir doughtir nat aword spak she
Non accident for non aduersitee
Was seyn in hir ne neuer ⁊andabsent:hirhirdoughter name
Ne nenenednemenednen⁊andi:enedshe for ernest ne for game
Incipit pars fabule ⁊andlb: cliiīm oxen
In this estate ther passid ben iiij yeer
Er she with childe but as god wolde
A knaue child she bar by this wauter
Ful gracious and fair for to biholde
And whan that folk it to his fadir tolde
Nat only he but al his contree merye
Was for this child and god they thank and herye
Whan it was two yeer old and fro the brest
Deꝑper/partid to his norice on a day
This Marquys right yit an othir lest
To tempte his wif yit ofter if he may
O needles was she temptid in assay
But wedded men ne knowe no mesure
Whan that they fynde a pacient creature
Wif quod this Marquys ye han herd or this
Mi peple seekly bereth oure mariage
And namely syn my sone y born is
Now is it worse than euere in al oure age
The murmur sleeth myn herte and my corage
For to myn eres comth the vois so smerte
That it welny destroyed hath myn hert
Now sey they thus whan wauter is a gon
Than shal the blook of Ianycle succede
And by our lord for other han we non
Swich wordis seith my peple it is no drede
Wel oght y of swich murmur taken heede
For certeynly y drede swich sentence
Though they nat pleyn speke in myn audience
I wold lyue in pees if that y myghte
Wherfore y am disposid vttirly
As y his sustir seruyd be nyghte
Right so thenke y to serue hym pryuely
This warne y you for ye not sodeynly
Out of youre self for no wo shulde outreye
Beth pacient and ther of y you preye
I haue quod heshehesheseyd thus and euere shal
I wol no thyng ne nyl no thyng certayn
But as you list nat greueth me at al
Thogh that my doughter and my sone be slayn
At your comaundement be slayn⁊andabsent:be slaynthat is to sayn
I haue nat had no part of children tweyne
But first seeknesse and after wo and peyne
Ye ben my lord do with your owne thyng
Right as you liste asketh no reed of me
For as Y lefte at home al my clothyng
Whan y first cam to you right so quod she
Lefte y my wille and al my liberte
And took youre clothyng wherfore y you preye
Doth your plesaunce y wol youre lust obeye
And certes if y hadde prescience
Youre wille to knowe or ye your lust lust⁊andabsent:lustme tolde
Y wold it do with outen neceligence
But now y wot your lust and what ye wolde
And youre plesaunce ferme and stabele y holde
For wist y that my deth myghte do you ese
Right gladly wolde y dye yow to plese
Deth may nat make no comaprison
Vn to our loue and whan this Marquys say
The constaunce of his wif he caste adoun
His eyen two and wondrith that she may
In pacience suffre al this array
And forth he goth with drery contenance
But to his hert it was righte gret plesance
This vgly sergeant in the same wyse
That he hir doghtir caghte right so he
Or werse if men werse can deuyse
Hath hent hir sone that ful was of beaute
And euer in on so pacient was she
That she no chere mad of heuynesse
But kyst hir sone and aftir gan it blesse
Saue this she preyed hym if that he myghte
Hir litel sone he wolde in erthe graue
His tendre lymes delicat to syghte
Fro foule and fro bestes for to saue
But she non answere of hym myghte haue
He wente his way as hym nothyng ne roghte
But ⁊andabsent:totoboloigne he tendrely it broghte
This marquys wonderth euer long the more
Vp on hir pacience if that he
Ne hadde sothly knowen ther byfore
That ꝑper/parfitly hir children loued she
He wolde han wend that of somme sotiltee
And of malice or for cruel corage
That she hadde suffred this with sad y⁊andabsent:yvisage
But wel he knew that next hym self certeyn
She loued hir children best in euery wise
But now of wommen wolde y asken feyyn
If this assaies myghten nat suffice
What coude a strudy housbonde more deuyse
To preue hir wifhod and hir stedfastnesse
And he contynuyng euere in strudinesse
But ther ben folk of which condicioıı̄un
That whan they han a certeyn purpos take
They can nat stynte of hir entencion
But right as they were bounde to a stake
They wol nat of hir first purpos slake
Right so this Maarquys fully hath purposid
To tempte his wif he was first disposid
He waiteth if by word or contenance
That she to hym was changed of corage
But neuere coude he fynde variaunce
She was ay on hert and in visage
And ay the ferthere that she was in age
The more trewe if that it were possible
She was to hym in loue⁊andabsent:loueloue and more penyble
For which it semeth thus that of hem two
Ther was but o wille for as waut̉er/re leste
That same lust was hir plesaunce also
And god bethankid al fil for the beste
She shewed wel for no wordly vnreste
A wif as of hir self no thyng ne shulde
Wille in effect but as hir housbonde wolde
Thesclaundre of wauter ofte and wyde spradde
That of a cruel herte he wikkedly
For he a pore womman wedded hadde
Hath murdrid both his childryn pryuely
Swich murmur was among hem comunly
No wondre is for to the peples ere
Ther cam no word but that they murdrid were
For which ther as his peple therbyfore
Had loued hym wel thesclaundre of his deffame
Made hem that they hym hateden therfore
To ben a murdrour is an hateful name
But nathelees for ernest ne for game
He of his cruel purpos nolde stente
To tempte his wif was set al his entent
Whan that this doghter twelue yeer was of age
He to the court of Rome in sotel wise
Enformed of his wille sent his message
Commaundyng hym sweche bulles to deuyse
As to his cruel purps may suffice
How that the pope as for his peples reste
Bad hym to wedde an other if hym leste
I sey he bad thei sholden countrefete
The popes bulles makyng mencion
That he hath leue his first wif to lete
And by the popes dispensacion
To stynte rancour and distesciondistensciondistenscion
Be twix his pl⁊andabsent:plpeple and hym thus spak the bulle
The which they han publisshed atte fulle
The rude peple as it no wondir is
Wenden ful wel that it hadde ben right so
But whan this tydyng cam to Grisildis
Y deme that hir hert was ful wo
But she y lyke sad for euer mo
Disposed was this humble creature
The aduercite of fortune to endure
Abydyng euere his luste and his plesance
To whom that she was yeuen herte and and⁊andabsent:andal
And to hir verry wordly suffisance
But shortly if this storie telle y shall
This marquys writen hath in special
A ⁊andlbar:re in which he shewith his entent
And seretly he to Boloigne it sente
To the Erl of pauyk which that hadde tho
Weddid his suster preide he specialy
To bryngyn hom agayn his children two
In honurable estat al openly
Cursith the day and tyme that nature
Shoop hym to ben a lyues creature
For out of dowte this olde pore man
Was euere in suspect of hir mariage
For euer he demede syn it first began
That whan the lord fulfild had his corage
Hym wolde thynke it were a disparage
To his estat so lowde for to alighete
And voiden here as sone as euer he myghte
Ageyn his doghter hastyly goth he
For he by noyse of folk knew hir comynge
And with an olde cote as it myght be
He couereth here sorowful wepyng
But on hir body myghte he it nat brygne
For rude was the cloth and more of age
Be dayes fele than hir mariage
Thus with hir fader for a certeyn space
Dwellith this flour of wifly pacience
That nowther by hir wordes ne hir face
Be forn the folk ne ek in hir absence
Ne shewed she that hir was doon offence
Ne of hir hye estat no remembrance
Nadde she as by hir contenance
No wonder is for in hir gret estat
Hir gost was euere in pleyn humylyte
To tendre mouth no herte delicat
No pompe no sembelant of realte
But ful of pacient benygnitee
Discret and pridelees ay honurable
And to hir housbonde euer meke ⁊andabsent:andandstable
Men speke of Iob and most for his hymblesse
As clerkes whan hem left can wel endite
Namly of men but as in sothfastnesse
Thogh clerkes preysen wommen but a lite
The can no man in humblesse hym v⁊andabsent:vaquyte
As womman can ne be half so trewe
As wommen be but it befalle of newe
Fro boloigne is this Erl of pauyk come
Of whichh the fame vp sprang to more and lesse
And ⁊andabsent:totothe peples eres alll and some
Was couth ek that a newe Marquysesse
He with hym broghte with swiche pompe and richesse
That neuer was ther seen with mannes eye
So noble aray in al westlumbardie
The marquys wich that shoop and knew al this
Or that this Erl was come sent his message
For thilk sely pore Grisildis
And she with humble herte and glad visage
Nat wih a swollen thoght in hir corage
Cam at his heste and on hir knees hir sette
And reuerently as wisly she hym grette
Grisilde quod he my wille is wittirly
This mayden that shal wedded be to me
Receyued be to morn is ryally
As possible is it in myn hous to be
And ek that euery wight in his degree
Haue his estat in sittyng and seruise
And hy plesauce as ye can best deuyse
I haue no womman suffisant certayn
The chaumbures for tarraye in ordynance
After my lust and therfore wold y fayn
That thyn were al swych maner gouernaunce
Thwou knowest ek of old al my plesaunce
Thogh thyn array be badde and euel beseye
Do thou they deuer atte leste weye
Nat only lord that y am glad quod she
To do youre lust but y desyre also
You for to serue and plese in my degre
With outyn feyntynge and shal euer mo
Ne neuere for no wele ne no wo
Ne shal the goost withynne myn herte stente
To loue you best with my trewe entente
And with that word the hous she gan to dighte
And tabeles for to sette and beddes make
And peyned here to do al that she myghte
Preyynge the chaumberes for goddes sake
To hastenhem faste to swepe and shake
And she the moste seruysable of alle
Hath euery chambre arraied and his halle
Abouten vndren gan this Erl talighte
And with hym broghte his noble children tweye
For which the peple ran to se the sighte
Of hir array so rechely byseye
And thanne at erst amonges hem they sey
That Wauter was no fool thou that hym lest
To chaunge his wif for it was for the beste
For she is fayrere as they demen alle
Thanne is Grisilde and more tendre of age
And fayrere fruyt bitwene hem shulde falle
And more plesant is for hir hy lynage
Hir brother ek so fair was of visage
That hem to see the peple hath caught plesance
Commendyng now the marquys goủer/renance
O stormy peple vnsad and euere vntrewe
And vndiscret and changynge as a fane
Delytyng ay in Rombil that is newe
For lyke the mone waxen ye and wane
Ay ful of clappyng deer ynow a Iane
Your doom is fals your constance euel preueth
A ful gret fool is he that on you leueth
Thus seyden sadde folk in that Citee
Whan that the peple gazed vp and doun
For they were glad right for the nouelte
To haue a new lady of the toun
No more of this now make y menciou
But to Grisilde anow wil y me dresse
And telle hir constance and hir busynesse
Ful bisily was Grisilde in euery thyng
That to the fest was apꝑper/partynent
Right naght was she abaist of hir clothynge
Thogh it were rude and sumdel ek to rent
But with glad cheere to the yate ys went
With othir folk to grete the Marquysesse
And after that doth forth hir busynesse
With so glad chere his gestes she receyueth
And konnyngly euerich in his degree
That no defaute no man apꝑper/parceyueth
But al they wondren what she myghte be
That in so pore array was for to see
And cowde swich honour and reuerence
And worthily they preysen hir prudence
In al this ⁊andi:⁊andi:eenemene⁊andi:⁊andi:emenewhiel she ne stent
This mayde and ek hir brother to comende
With al hir herte in ful benyngne entente
So wel that no man coude hir preydpreyspreydsamende
But at laste whan this lordes wende
To sitten doun to mete he gan to calle
Grisilde as she was bisy in his halle
Grysilde quod he as it were in his pley
How likith the my wif and here beaute
Right wel quod she my lord for in good fay
A fairere saw y neuere no than she
Y pray to god yeue yow prosꝑper/paritee
And so y hope that he woll to you sende
Plesance y now vn to your lynes ende
O thyng biseke y you and warne also
That ye ne prike with no turmentynge
This tendre mayden as ye han do mo
For she is fostrid in hir norissynge
More tenderly and to my supposynge
She myghte nat aduersitee endure
As coude a poore fostrid creature
And whan this Wauter saw hir pacience
Hir glad chere and no malice at al
And he so often hadde hir doon offence
And she ay sad and constant as awal
Contynyng eủer/ree hir Innocence oủer/real
This sturdy Marquys gan his herte to besse
To rewe vpon hir wifly stedfastnesse
This is y now Grisilde myn quod he
Be now no more agast and euel apyed
Y haue thi feith and thi benygnyte
As wel as euer womman was assayed
In gret estat ⁊andabsent:andandporelyche arayed
Now knowe y dere wif thi stedfastnesse
And here in armes took and gan hir kysse
And she for wonder took of it no keep
She herde nat of it what thyng he to hir seyde
She ferde as she had stirt out of hir sleep
Til she out or hir mazidnesse abreyde
Grisilde quod he by god that for vs deide
Thou art my wif ne non other y haue
Ne neuere hadde so god my sowle saue
This is thi doghter which thou hast supposid
To be my wif that othir feithfully
Shal be myn heyr as y haue ay purposyd
Thou baar hem in thi body trewly
At boloigne haue y kept hem pryuely
Taak hem agayn for now maistow nat seye
That thou hast lorn non of thi children tweye
And folk that othir weyes han seyd of me
Y warne hem wel that y haue doon this dede
For no malice ne no crueltee
But for tassaye in the thi wommanhede
And nat to slee my children god for bede
But for to kepe hem preuely and stille
Til y thi purpos knew and ek wille
Whan she this herde a swoun doun she fallith
For pytous ioye and after hir swounynge
She bothe his yonge children to hir callithe
And in hir armes pitously wepynge
Embraceth hem and tendrely kyssynge
Ful lik a modir with hir salte teres
She bathid bothe hir visages and hir heres
O whiche a pitous thyng it was to see
Hir swounynge and hir humble vois to here
Grand mercy lord god thanke it you quod she
That ye han saued me my children deere
Now rekke y neuere to be deed right heere
Syn y stonde in youre loue and in youre grace
No fors of deth ne whan my spirit pace
O tendir.o.dere.o.yonge children myne
Youre woful modir wende stedefastly
That creuel houndes or sum foul vermeyne
Hadde eten you but god of his mercy
And youre benygne fadir tendrely
Hath doon you kepte and in the same stounde
Al sodeynly she swapte a doun to grounde
And in hir swoun so sadly holdith she
Hir children two whan she gan hem embrace
That with gret sleythe and gret difficulte
The children from hir arme they gan arare
O many tere and many a pitous face
Doun ran of hem that stonden here biside
Wifles hath ben thogh that men wolde hym Ryue
Vn to the herte ne koude in no manere
Tellen so moche sorwe as y you here
Koude telle of my wifes cursidnesse
No quod oure hoost Marchaund so god you blesse
Syn ye so mochel knowe of that art
Ful hertely y prey you telle vs part
Gladly quod he but of myn owne sore
For sori hert y telle may no more

div.l: A worthi knyght he leued in gret proꝑper/parspite that bore was yn peuye
In which he leued in gret prosꝑper/parite
And . lx . yeer a wifles man was he
And folowed his body delyte
On wommen ther as was his apetite
As do thise foles that ben seculer
And whanne he was passid x lx yeer
Were it for holinesse or for dotage
Y can nat sey but swich agret corage
Hath this knyght to ben a wedded man
That day and nyght he doth al that he can
Tespien where he myghte weddid be
Preyinge oure lord to graunte hym that he
Might knowe ones of that blisful lif
That is bitwixe an husbonde and his wif
And for to leue vndir that holy bonde
With which that god man and womman bonde
Noon othir lif seyde he is worth a bene
For wedlok is so esy and so clene
That it is in hym self a paradis
Thus seyde this olde knyght that was so wys
And certeynly as soth as god is kyng
To take a wif it is a glorious thyng
And namely whan aman is old and hoor
Thanne is a wif ye furst of his tre soor
Thanne shuld he take a yonge wif and afeir
On which he myght engendren hym an Eyer
And lede his lif in yoye and solas
Where as thise bachelers synge allas
Whan that they fynde any aduersitee
In loue which nys but childisshe vanitee
And trewely it sit wel to be soo
That bachilers haue ofte peyne and woo
On brytil ground they bilde and brotilnesse
They fynde whan they wene sikernesse
Thei leue but as a bird or as a beste
In lybertee and vndir noon areste
Ther as a weddid man in his estate
Lyueth a lyf blisful and ordenate
Vndir this yok of mariage y bounde
Wel may his herte in ioye and blisse habounde
For ho can be so boxom as a wif
Who is so trewe and ek so ententif
To kepe hym seek and hool as is his make
For weele or wo she wil hym nat for sake
She is nat wery hym to loue and serue
Thoght he be bedrede til that he sterue
And yit some clerkes sey it is nat soo
Of which he theofrast is on of thoo
What fors thogh theofrast list for to lye
Ne take no wif quod for he for housboundrye
As for to spare in housholde they dispence
A trewe seruant doth more diligence
Thi good to kepe than thyn oune wif
For she wil clayme half part al hir lyf
And yf thou be seek so god me saue
Thy verrey frendes or a trewe knaue
Wol kepe the bet than she that waiteth ay
Aftir thi good and hath doon many a day
And if thou take a wif be wel y war
Of on thyng whiche y declare nedar
This sentence and an hundred thynges worse
Writith this man ther god his bones corse
But take no kepe of al such vanitee
Diffie Theofrast and herkene me
A wif is goddes yifte verrayly right
Alle other maner yiftes hardyly
As londes rentes pasture or comune
Thise bith the yiftes of fortune
That passen as a shadowe on the wal
But drede thou nat if pleynly speke y shal
A wif wol last and in thyn hous endure
Wel lengere than the list ꝑper/parauenture
Mariage is a ful gret sacrament
He which that hath no wif y holde hym shent
He leuyth helpelees and al desolat
Y speke of folk in seculere estat
And herkyn whi y sey nat this for noght
That womman is for mannes helpe y wroght
The hye god whan he hadde Adam y maked
And saugh hym allone baly naked
God of his greet goodnesse seyde thanne
Let vs now make an helpe vn to this manne
Lik to hym self and thanne he made hym Eue
Here may ye se and here may ye preue
That wif is mannes helpe and confort
His paradis terrestre and his disport
So buxom and so vertuous is shee
They moste nede lyue in vnitee
O flessh they ben and o flessh as y gesse
Hath but on herte in wele and in distresse
A wif a seynte Marie benedicite
How myght a man haue any aduersitee
That hath a wif certes y can nat seye
The blisshe the which is betwex hem tweye
Ther may no tonge telle or herte thynke
Yif he be poore she helpeth hym to swynke
She kepith his good and wasteth neuer adel
Al that hir husbonde doth hir liketh wel
She seith nat ones nay whan he seith ye
Do this seyth he al redy syre seith she
O blisful ordre o wedlok precious
Thou art so murie and ek so vertuous
And so comended and approued ek
That ony man that holt hym worth a leke
Vp on his bare knees oghte al his lif
Thanken his god that hym hath sente a wif
Or elles preye to god hym for to sende
A wif to laste vn to his lyues ende
For than his lif is set in sikernesse
He may nat be desceyued as y gesse
So that he werche after his wifes reed
Than may he boldely kepen vp his hed
They byn so trewe and ther with so wise
For which yif thou wolt worchen as the wyse
Do alwey so as wommen wol the reede
Lo how that Iacob as this clerkis reede
Be good conseil of his moder Rebekke
Boond the kydes skyn aboute his nekke
For which his fadres benesou he wan
Loo Iudith as the story ek telle kan
By gode conseil she goddes peple kepte
And slogh hym Olofernes whil he slepte
Loo Abygayl by good conseil how she

The peple of god and made hym Mardochee

Ther nys no thyng in gree suꝑper/parlatif
As seith senek a boue an humble wif
Suffre thi wyues tonge as Caton bit right
She comande and thou shalt suffren it
And yit she wol obeye of curtesye
A wif is kepere of thyn husbondrie
Wel may the seek man bewayle and wepe
Ther as is no wif the hous to kepe
I warne the yf wisily thou wolt werche
Loue wel thi wif as crist loueth his cherche
Yif thou louest thi self thou louest thi wif
Noman hatith his flessh but in his lif
He Fostred hit and therfore bid he the
Cherisshe thi wif or thou shalt neuer the
Housbonde and wif what so men iape or pleye

And namely vp on the wyues syde
For which this Ianuarie of hom y tolde
Considered hath in which his dayes olde
The lusty lif the vertuous quyetee
That is in mariage hony swete
And for his freendes on a day he sente
To tellen hem theffect of his entente
With face sad this tale he hath hem tolde
He seyde freendes y am hoor and olde
And almost god woot on my pittes brynke
Vp on my soule sumwhat most y thynke
I haue my body folily despended
Blessid be god that y shal ben amended
For y wol be certeyn a weddid man
And that a non in al the hast y can
Vn to some mayde fair and tendre of age

And y wol fonde tespien on my syde

And ek thise old wedues god it woot

But certeynly yonge thyng men may gye

Wherfore y sey you pleynly in a clause

Thanne sholde y lede my lif in a uoutrye

Ne children shulde y noon vp on hir geten

In straunge hondes and this y telle you alle
I doute nat y woot the cause whi

Ther speketh many a man of mariage

For which causes a man shulde take a wif
Yf he ne may nat leue in chastitee his lif
Take hym a wif with gret deuociou
Be cause of leueful ꝓprocreaciou
Of children to honour of god a boue
And nat only for ꝓproamour or for loue
And for they shulde leccherie eschue
And yelde her dette whan that it is due
And for that ech of hem shulde helpen other
In meschif as a suster shal the brother

But sires by youre leue that am nat I
For god be thanked y dar make auaunt
I fele my lymes stark and sufficiant

I woot my self best what y may doo
Thogh y be hoor y fare as doth a tre

Dyuers men diuersly hym tolde

Mayus that sit with so benygne acher
Hir to beholde it semede me fayrie
Queen Ester lookyd neuer with swiche an eye
On assuer so meke alook hath she
Y may you nat deuyse l al hir beaute
But thus moche of hir beaute telle y may
That she was lik the brighte morwe of may
Fulfilled of al beaute and plesaunce
This Ianuarye is rauysshid in a traunce
At euery tyme he lokith on hir face
But in his herte he gan hir to manace
That he that myght in armes wolde hir stryne
Harder than euer Paris dede Eleyne
But nathelees yit hadde he gret pyte
That thik nyght offenden here most he
And thoghte alas o tendre creature
Now wol god ye myghten wel endure
Al my corage it is so sharp and kene
I am a gast y shul it not sustene
But god forbede that y dede al my myght
Now wold god that it were waxen nyght
And that the nyght wolde lasten euer mo
I wold that al this peple were agoo
And fynally he doth al his labour
As he best myghte sauyng his honour
To haste hem fro the mete in sotil wise
The tyme cam that reson was to rise
And aftir that men daunce and drynken faste
And spices al aboute the hous they caste
And ful of yoye and blisse is euery man
Sauynge a squyer highte damyan
Wiche carf beforn the knyght ful many aday
He was so rauysshit on his laydy may
That for the verray peyne he was ny wood
Almost he swelte and swouned as he stood
So sore hath venus hurt hym with here word brond
As that she bar it daunsyng in here hond
And to his bed he wente hym hastily
No more of hym as at this tyme speke I
But there y lete hym wepe ynow and pleyne
Til fressh may wil rewen on his peyne
O ꝑper/parillous fir that in the bedstrau bredith
O famuler fo that hye seruice bedith
O seruant traytour false homly hewe
Lik to the nedder in bosom sly ontrewe
God shelde vs al from youre aquyntaunce
O Ianuarie dronken in plesaunce
In mariage se how thy bore man
Thyn owene squyer callid damyan
Ententith for to do the vylenye
God graunte the thyn homly foo for tospie
For in this world nys werse pestilence
Than homly fo alday in thi psence
Parformed hath the sonne his arke dyurne
Ne lengere may the body of hym soiorne
On the orizonte as in that latitude
Night with his mantel that is derk and rude
Gan ouer sprede themisꝑper/parie a boute
For which departid is this lusti route
Fro Ianuarie with thank on euery syde
Hom to hir houses lustily they ryde
Where as they doon hir thynges as hem leste
And whan they saw hir tyme go to reste
Sone after that this hastif Ianuarie
Wol go to bedde he wol no lengere tarye
He drynkith ypocras clarre and vernage
Of spices hote tencrecen his corage
And many a letuarie hadde he ful fyne
Swich as the cursed munke dan Costantyn
Hath wreten in his book de coytu
To ete hem alle he was no thyng eschu
And to his pryue frendes thus seyde he
For goddis loue as sone as it may be
Let voiden al this hous in curteys wise
And they han doon right as he wol deuyse
Men dronken and the trauers drowen anon
The bride is broght abedde as stille as ston
And whan the bedde was with the prest y blessed
Out of the chaumbre hath euery wight hym dressed
And Ianuarie hath fast in armes take
His fressh may his peradis his make
He lullith here he kissith here ful ofte
With thilke bristeles of his berd vnsofte
Lik to the skyn of houndfissh sharp as brer
For he was shaue al newe in his manere
He rubbith here aboute hir tendre face
And seid thus allas y mot trespace
To you my spouse and you gretly offende
Or tyme come that y wol doun decende
But nathelees considerith this qd he
Ther nys no werkman what so eủer/ree he be
That may bothe werkyn wel and hastily
This wol be doon at leyser parfitly
Hit is no force how longe that we pleye
In trewe wedlok couplid be we tweye
And blessed be the yok that we ben Inne
For in oure actes may there be no synne
A man may do no synne with his wif
Ne hurte hym seluen with his owne knyf
For we haue leue to pleye vs by the lawe
Thus labourth he til the day gan dawe
And than he takith a sop in fyn clarr
And vpright in his bed thanne sittith he
And aftir that he sang ful lowle and cleere
And kist his wif and made wanton cheere
He was al coltissh fullof ragerie
And ful of iergou as a flekked pie
The slakke skyn aboute his nekke shakith
Whil that he sang so chauntith he and crakith
But god wot what that may thoghte in hir herte
Whan she hym sey vp sittyng in his sherte
In his nyghte cappe and with his nekke lene
She preysith nat his pleyyng worth a bene
Than seyde he thus my reste wol y take
Now day is come y may no lengere wake
And doun he leyde his heed and sleep til pryme
And aftirward whan he saw his tyme
Vp riseth Ianuarie but fressh May
Heeld hir in chaumbre vn to the iiijthe day
As vsage is of wyues for the beste
For euery labour sumtyme muste han reste
Or elles longe may he nat endure
This is to seyn no lyues creature
Be it fissh or bird or beste or man
Now wol y speke of woful damyan
That langwisshit in loue as ye shul here
Therfore y speke to hym in this manere
I sey o sely Damyan allas
Answere to my demaunde as in this cas
How shalt tow to thy lady fressh may
Telle thi wo she wol alwey sey nay
Ek if thou speke she wol thy wo biwreye
God be thyn help y can no betere seye
This sike damyan in venus fir
So brennyth that he dyeth for desir
For whiche he put his lif in auentur
No lenger myght he in this wise endure
But pryuely a pennere gan he borwe
And in a lre wrot he al his sorwe
In maner of a compleynt or a lay
Vn to his faire fresshe lady May
And in a purs of sylk heeng on his sherte
He hath it put and leyde it at his herte
The moone that at noon was thilke day
That Ianuarie hath wedded fressh may
In to syn of taur was in to Cancer gleden
So longe hath Mayus in his chambre abiden
As custume ys vn to this nobles alle
Abryde shal nat eten in the halle
Til dayes . iiij . or . iij . dayes atte leste
Y passed ben than lat here go to feste
The . iiij . day compleet fro noon to noon
When that the hye messe was y doon
In halle sit this Ianuarie and may
As fressh as is the brighte someres day
And so be fil how that this goode man
Remembrid hym vpon this damyan
And seyd seynte marie how may this be
That damyan entendith nat to me
Is he ay sik or how this betide
His squyers whichas stoden ther be syde
Excusid hym be cause of his siknesse
Non other cause myght make hym tarie
That me forthynkith qd this Ianuarie
He is a gentil squyer by my trowthe
If that he deyde it were gret harm and rowthe
He is as wis discret and as secree
As ony man y wot of his degree
And ther to manly and ek seruysable
And for to byn athirfty man right able
But aftir mete as sone as euer y may
I wol my self visite hym and ek may
To don hym al the comfort that y can
And for that word hym blessed euery man
That of his bounte and his gentilnesse
He wolde hym so conforten in siknesse
His squyer for it was a gentil dede
Dame quod this Ianuarie take god hede
At aftir mete ye with youre wommen alle
Whan that ye been yn chamber out of this halle
That al ye goo to se damyan
Doth hym desport he is a gentil man
And tellith hym that y wol hym visite
Haue y nothyng but restyd me alyte
And spede you faste for y wol abide
Til that ye slepe faste be my syde
And with that word he gan vn to hym calle
A squyer that was Mareschal of his halle
And tolde hym serteyn thynges that he wold
This fressh may hath streight here weye y holde
With al hir wommen vn to Damyan
Doun bi his beddes side sit she thanne
Comfortyng hym as goodly as she may
This damyan whan he his tyme say
In secret wise his purs and ek his bille
In whiche that he y writen hadde his fille
Hath put in to hir hand with outen more
Saue that he sikit wonder depe and sore
And softely to hir right thus seide he
Mercy and that ye discouere not me
For y am deed if that this thyng be kyd
This purs hath she inwith here bosom hyd
And wente hir wey ye gete no more of me
But vn to Ianuarie y comen is she
That on his beddes syde sat ful softe
And taketh here and kissith here ful ofte
And leyde hym doun to slepe and that a non
She feyned here ther as she muste gon
Ther as ye wot that euery wight mot nede
And whan she of this bille hath taken hede
She rente it al to cloutes at the laste
And in the pryue softeliche hit cast
Who studieth now but faire fresshe may
A doun by olde Ianuarie she lay
That slepte til that þe cowhe had hym awakyd
A non preyde hire strepen hir al naked
He wolde of here haue sumplesaunce
He seyde hir clothes dede hym encoumbraunce
And she abeyeth hym be here lef or loth
But lest that precious folk be wroth
How that he wroghte y dar nat to you telle
Or wheyder hir thoghte hit ꝓproadis or helle
But there y lete hem werken in hir wise
Til euesong rang and that they muste aryse
Where it be destenye or auenture
Where it be by influence or nature
Or constellaciou that in sweche estat
The heuene stood at that tyme fortunat
As for to putte a bille of venus werkes
For al thyng hath tyme as sey clerkes
To eny womman for to gete hir loue
I kan nat seyn but gret god a boue
That knoweth that noon act is causelees
He deme of al for y wol holde my pees
But soth is this how that this fresshe may
Hath taken swich impressiou that day
For pite of this sike Damyan
That from hir herte she ne dryue can
The remenbraunce for to do hym ese
Serteyn thoghte she whom that this thyng displese
I rekke nat for here y hym assure
To loue hym best of ony creature
Thogh he nomor hadde than his bar sherte
Lo pite renneth sone in gentil herte
He may ye seen how excellent fraunchise
In wommen is whan they hem narwe auyse
Su tyraunt is as therbyen many on
That hath an herte as hard as any stoon
Which wolde han lete hym storuen in that place
Wel rather than han grauntid hym hir grace
And hem reioisen in hir crewel pryde
And rekken nat to been an homycide
This gentil may fulfild of pite
Right of hir hand a lre maketh she
In which she grauntith hym hir grace
Ther k lakketh nat but only day and space
Where that she myghte vn to his loust suffise
For it shal be right as he wol deuyse
And whan she saw hir tyme vp on a day
To visiten this damyan goth this faire may
And sotilli this lre doun she threste
Vndir his pilwe red it if hym leste
She takith hym by the hond and harde hym twiste
So secretly that no wight of it wiste
And bad hym ben al hool and forth she wente
To Ianuarie whan that he for here sente
Vp risith damyan the nexte morwe
Al passed was his siknesse and his sorwe
He kymbith hym he proyneth hym and pyketh
He doth al that his lady lust and liketh
And ek to Ianuarie he goth as lowe
As euery dede adogge for the bowe
He is so plesaunt vn to euery man
For craft is al ho so that don can
That euery wight is fayn to speke hym good
And fully in his ladyes grace he stood
Thus lete y Damyan aboute his nede
And my tale forth y wol procede
Sum clerkes holden that felicity
Stant in delit and therfore certeyn he
This nobele Ianuarie with al his myght
In honest wise as longith vn to a knyght
Shoop hym to leuen ful deliciously
His housyng his array as honestly
To his degree was makid as a kynges
Amonges othir of his honest thynges
He made agardyn wallid al with stoon
So fair a gardyn wot y nowher noon
For out of doute y verayly suppose
That he that made the romaunce of the rose
Ne coude of hit the beaute dyuyse
Ne pryapus ne myght nat suffice
Thogh he be god of gardyns for to telle
The beaute of the gardeyn and the welle
That stood vnder a laurer alway grene
Ful often tyme he pluto and his queene
Proserpina and al here fayerye
Desporten hem and makyn melodye
Aboute that welle and daunced as men tolde
This noble knyght this Ianuarie the olde
Sweche deynte hath in hit to walke and pleye
That he wol no wight suffre bere the keye
Sauf he hym self for of the smal wiket
He ber alwes of siluer a clyket
With the which whan that hym list he it vnshette
And whan he wold paye his wif his dette
In somer sesou thider wol he go
And may his wif an nowight but they two
And thynges whiche that were nat don abedde
He in the gardeyn ꝓproformed hem and spedde
And in this wise many amery day
Leued this Ianuarie and fresshe may
But worldly ioye may nat alwey dure
To Ianuarie ne to no creature
O sodeyn hap o thow fortune vnstable
Lik to the scorpiou so deceyuable
That flaterist with thyn heed whan thou wost stynge
Thi tail is deth thurgh thyn enuenymynge
O brotel ioye o swete venym queynte
O monstre that so sotilly canst peynte
Thi yiftes vnder hew of stedefastnesse
That thou deceyuest bothe more and lesse
Whi hastow Ianuarie thus deceyued
That haddest hym for thi ful frend receyued
And now thou hast biraft hym bothe his eyen
For sorwe of whiche desirest he to dyen
Alas thys nobele Ianuarie free
Amydde his lust and his prosꝑper/parite
Is waxen blynd and that al sodeynly
He wepith and he wayleth pytously
And ther with al the fir of Ielousye
Lest that his wif shulde falle in som folye
So brente his herte that he wolde fayn
That sum man hadde bothe hym and her y slayn
For nouther his deth ne in his lif
Ne wolde he that she were loue ne wif
But euer lyue as a widwe in clothes blake
Soul as the Turtel that hath lost hir make
But atte laste aftir amonthe or tweye
His sorwe gan asswage soth to seye
For whan he wiste it may non othir be
He paciently tok his aduersitee
Saue out of doute he ne may nat forgoon
That he nas gelous euermor in on
Whiche ielosie it was so outragious
That neyther in halle ne in non other hous
Ne in non othir place neuer the mo
He nolde suffre hir for to ride or goo
But if that he hadde hond on here alway
For which ful often wepid fressh may
That loueth Damyan so benyngly
That she muste outher dien sodeynly
Or elles she muste han hym as hir leste
She waytith whan hir herte wold breste
Vp on that othir syde Damyan
Bycome is the wofuleste man
That euere was for neyther nyght ne day
Ne myghte he speke a word to fressh may
As to his purpos of no swiche matere
But if that Ianuarie muste hit here
That hadde an hand vp on hir eueremo
But natheles by writyng to and fro
And pryue signys wist she what he mente
And she knew ek the fyn of his entente
O Ianuarie what myghte hit the auayle
Thou that myghtist se as fer as shippis sayle
For as good is al blynd deceyued be
As be deceyued whan a man may se
Lo Argus which that hadde an . C eyen
For al that euere he coude poure or pryen
Yit was he blent god wot and so ben mo
That wenen wisly that it be nat soo
Passe ouer is an esse y sey no more
This Fresshe may of the whiche y spak of yore
In warm wex hath enprented the cleket
That Ianuarie bar of that smale wyket
By whiche onto his gardyn ofte he wente
And damyan that knew al his entente
The clyket contrefetid pryuely
Ther nys no more to sey but hastyly
Sum wondir bi this cliket shal betyde
Which ye shul here if that ye wol abide
O noble ouyde soth seystow god wot
That sleythe is hy if loue be longe and hoot
That he nyl fynde it out in sum manere
By piramus and tisbe may men lere
Thogh they were kept ful longe and streit oủer/ree al
They byen acordid rownynge thourgh a wal
There no wigh coude han founde out swich a sleyghte
But now to purpos or that dayes . viijᵉ .
Were passed of the monthe of Iul be fil
That Ianuarie hath caght so greet a wil
Thurgh eggynge of his wif hym for to pleye
In his gardyn and no wight but they tweye
That in a morwen vn to may seyde he
Rise vp my wif my loue my lady free
The turtiles vois is herd myn owne swete
The wyntir is goon with alle his reynes wete
Come forth now with thyn eyen Columbyn
Wel fairere be thi brestes that is ony wyn
The gardyn is enclosed a boute
Come forth my white spouse out of doute
Thou hast me woundid in my herte o wif
No spot in the nas neuere in al thi lif
Come forth and lat vs taken our disport
I chese the for my wif and my comfort
Swiche olde lewed wordes vsed he
On damyan a signe made she
That he shulde go biforn with his clyket
This damyan hath opened the wiket
And in he sterte and that in swich manere
That no wight myghte it se ne here
And stil he sit vndir abussh a noon
This Iāmuarie as blynd as is a ston
With mayus in his hond and no wight mo
In to this fressh gardeyn is goo
And clapte to the wiket sodeynly
Now wif qd he hir nys but thou and y
That art the creature that y best loue
For by that lord Ihu that sit aboue
Y hadde leuere dyen on a knyf
Thanne the offenden dere trewe wif
For goddes sake thynke how y the ches
Nat for no couytise douteles
But only for the loue y hadde to the
And thou that y be old and may nat see
Beth to me trewe and y wol tel you whi
Certes iijᵉ thynges shul ye wynne ther bi
First loue of crist and to youre self honour
And al myn heritage toun and tour
I yeue you makith chartres as you leste
This shal be doon to morwe or sonne reste
So wisly god my sowle brynge to blysse
And preye you on this couenant ye me kisse
And thogh that y be Ielus wyte me noght
Ye ben so depe enpreyntid in my thoght
That whan that y considere your beaute
And ther with al thunlikly elde of me
I may nat certes thogh y shulde dye
Forbere to ben out of youre compaignye
For verray loue this is with outen dowte
Now kisse me wif and lat vs rome aboute
This fressh may whan she this wordes herde
Benygnely to Ianuarie answede
But first and forward she be gan to wepe
I haue quod she ꝓprode a sowle for to kepe
As wel as ye and also myn honour And of my wifhod
And of my wifhod thilke tendre flour
Which that y haue assured in youre hond
Whan that the prest to you my body bond
Where fore y wol answere in this manere
With leue of you myn owne lord so dere
Y pray god dawe neuere thilke day
That y ne sterue as foule as womman may
Yf euere y do my kyn that shame
Or elles y empeyre so myn name
That y be fals and if y do that lak
Do stripe me and pute me in a sak
And in the next reuer do me drenche
I am a gentel womman and no wenche
Whi speke ye thus but men ben euere ontrewe
And wommen han of you reprif ay newe
Ye conne non othir contenaunce y leue
But speke to vs of vtrist in repreue
And with that word she say where damyan
Sat in the busshe and cowhen she be gan
And with here fynger signes made she
That damyan shulde clymbyn in a tree
That chargid was with fruyt and vp he went
For verraily he knew al hir entente
And euery sygne that she cowde make
For in a lre she hadde told hym al
Of this matere how that he werken shal
And thus y lete hym syttynge in the pirie
And Ianuarie and may romynge ful merie
Bright was that day and blew the firmament
Phebus of gold doun hath his stremes sent
To glaydyn euery flour with his warmnesse
He was that tyme in geminys y gesse
But litil fro his declynaciou
Of Cancer Ioues exaltaciou
And so be fil that brighte morwe tyde
That in the gardyn on the ferthere syde
Pluto that is the kyng of fayrye
And many alady in his compaignye
Folwyng his wif the quene proserpina
Which that he rauysshed out of Ethna
Whil that she gaderid floures in a mede
In Claudyan ye may the storye rede
How that here in his grysly carte he sette
This kyng of fayrie adoun hym sette
Vp on a bench of turues fressh and grene
And right a non seyde he thus to his quene
Mi wif quod he ther may no wight sey nay
The exꝑper/parience preueth hit euery day
The tresou which that womman doth to man
Ten C Mˢ stories telle y can
Notabele of youre vntrowthe and brotilnesse
O Salamon richest of al richesse
Fulfild of Sapience and wordly glorie
Fulworthi ben thi wordes to han in memorie
To euery wight that wit and reson can
Thus preyset he the bounte yit of man
Among a Mˢ men yt fonde y on
But of al wommen fond y neuere non
Thus seith this kyng that knew youre wikkednesse
And Ihus filius Sirak as y gesse
Ne spekith of you but selden reuerence
A wilde fir a corupt pestilence
So falle vp on youre bodyes yit to nyght
Ne seye nat this honurable knyght
By cause allas he is blynd and old
His oune man shal make hym Cokewold
Lo where he sit the leccheour in the tree
Now wol y grauntyn of my magestee
Vn to this olde blynde worthi knyght
That he shal haue ageyn his eyen sight
Whan that his wif wol don hym vilenye
Than shal he knowe al hir harlatrie
Bothe in repref of here and othir mo
Ye shal quod proserpina and wol ye so
Now be my modres ceres soule y swere
That y shal yeue here sufficiaunt answere
And alle women aftir for hir sake
That thogh they ben in ony gilt y take
With face bold they shul hem selue excuse
And bere hem doun that wolden hem acuse
For lak of answere non of vs shal dyen

rdg.seg: Al hadde ye seen al thyng wᵗith bothe your yen

div.l: Yit shul we so visage hit hardily
And wepe and swere and chiden subtilly
That ye shul ben as w lewed s as ben gees
What rekkith me of youre youre autoritees
I wot wel that this Iew this salomon
Fand of vs women fooles many on
But thogh that he ne fond no good womman
Ther hath y funden many an other man
Wommen ful goode and trewe and vertuous
Witnesse on hem that dwelte in Cristes hous
With Martirdom they preued her Constance
The Romayn gestes maken remembrance
Of many a verray trewe wif al soo
But sere ne be nat wroth al be it soo
Thogh that he seyde he fond no good womman
I preye you take the sentence of the man
He mente thus that in souereyne bounte
Nis non but god no nouthir he ne she
Ey for the verray god that nys but on
What make ye so moche of Salamon
What thoght he made a temple goddes hous
What thogh he were riche and glorious
So made he ek a temple of false goddes
Who myghte doon a thyng that more forbode is
Parde as faire as ye his name emplastre
He was a lecchour and a ydolastre
And in his elde he verray god forsook

rdg.seg: And if that god ne hadd as seith the book

div.l: Sparid hym for his faderis sake he sholde
Han lost his regne sounere than he wolde
I set not of al the vilenye
That he of womme writ a botirflie
I am a womman nedes muste y speke
Or swelle vn to that tyme myn herl herte breke
For syn he seyde we be Iangleresses
As euere mote y wel browke my tresses
I shal nat spare for no curtesie
To speke hym harm that seith vs vilenye
Dame quod this pluto be no lengere wroth
I yeue it vp but syn y swor an oth
That y wolde grauntyn hym his sight agayn
Mi word shal stande that warne y the serteyn
I am a kyng it sit me not to lye
And y quod she am quene of fairie
Here answershal she han y vndirtake
Let vs no more wordes of it make
For sothe quod he y wol you nat contrarie
Now let vs turne a gayn to Ianuarie

l.hi: Ordynges quod he in chirchis whan I preche

div.l: I peyne me to haue an hauteyn speche
And rynge hit out as rounde as goth a bille
For y can al by rote that I telle
My teme is alway on and euere was
First I pronounce whennes y come
And thanne my bullis sw shewe I alle and some
Our lege lordes seel on my patente
That shewe I first my body to warente
That no man be so bold no preest ne clerk
Me to destorbe of cristes holy werk
And aftir that thanne telle y forth my tales
Bullis of popes and of cardinales
Of patriarkes and bisshoppes I shewe
And in latyn y speke awordes Fewe
To saffron with my predicaciou
And for to stere hem to deuociou
Thanne shew y forth my longe cristal stonis
I crammed ful of clowtes and of bonis
Relikis they ben as wenen they echou
Thanne haue I in latou a shuldre bon
Which that was of an hooly Iewes shep
Good men sey I take of my wordes keep
If that this bon be wasshe in ony welle
If cow or calf or sheep or oxe swelle
That ony wronn hath ete or worm ystonge
Take watir of that welle and wasshe his tonge
And it is hool anon and forthermor
Of pokkes and of scabbe and eueri sor
Shal eueri sheep be hol that of this welle
Drynkith a draght take keep ek what y telle
If that the goodman that the beestes owith
Wole euery weke or that the cok hym crowith
Fastyng drynkyn of this welle a draght
As thilke holy Iew our eldres taghte
His bestes and his stoor shal multiplye
And sere also hit helith Ielousie
For thogh a man be fallen in Ielous rage
Lat makyn with this water his potage
And neuere shal he more his wif mistriste
Thogh he the sothe of hir defaute wiste
Al haue she taken prestes two or three
Heer is a myten ek that ye may see
He that his hand wil putte in this myteyn
He shal haue multiplyynge of his greyn
Whan he hath sowen be hit whete or otes
So that they offre pens or elles grootes
goodmen and wommen o thyng warne y you
If ony wight be in this chirche nowe
That hath doon synne horible that he
Dar not for shame of hit y shryuen be
Or ony womman be she yong or old
That hath ymaad hir housbonde Cok wold
Swich folk shul han no power ne no grace
To offre to my Reliques in this place
And ho so fyndith hym out of swiche blame
He wol come vp and offre a goddes name
And y assoile hym be the autorite
Which that be bulle grauntid was to me
by this gaude haue y wonnen euery yeer
An C . mark syn y was Pardoner
. I stonde lik a clerk in my pulpit
And whan the lewed peple is doun yset
I preche so as ye han herd before
And telle an C falce iapes more
Thanne peyne y me to strecch forth the nekke
And Est and west vp on the peple y bekke
As doth a dowue syttyng on a berne
Mym hondes and my tonge gon so yerne
That it is ioye to see my bisinesse
Of auerice and of swich cursidnesse
Is al my prechyng for to make hem free
To yeue hir pens and manely vn to me
For myn entent is naght but for to wynne
And no thyng for correcciou of synne
I recke neuere whan that they be beried
Thogh that hir sowles gon a blakeberied
For certes many a predicaciou
Comyth often tyme of il entenciou
For sum plesance of folk and flaterie
To ben auanced by ypocrecye
And sum for veyn glorie and sum for hate
For whan y dar non othir weyes debate
Thanne wil y stynge hym with my tonge smerte
In prechyng so that he shal nat asterte
To be defamed falsly if that he
Hath trespased to my brethern or to me
For thogh y telle nought his propre name
Men shul wel knowen that hit is the same
Be sygnes an be othir circumstances
Thus quyte y folk that don vs displesances
Thus spitte y out my wenem vndir hewe
Of holynesse to seme holy and trewe
But shortly my entent y wol deuyse
I preche of no thyng but for coueytyse
Therfore my teme is yit and euere was
thus can y preche ageyn the same vice
Which that y vse and that is auerice
But thogh myselue be gilte in that synne
Yit can I maken othir folk to twynne
From auerice and sore to repente
But that is nat my pryncipal entente
I preche nothyng but for coueytise
Of this mater hit owghte y now suffice
Thanne telle y hem ensamples many on
Of olde stories longe tyme agon
For lewde peple louen tales olde
Swich thynges can they wel reporte and holde
What trowe ye that whiles y may preche
And wynne gold and siluer for y teche
That y wol leue in pouert wilfully
Nay nay I thoghte hit neuere trewely
For y wol preche and begge in sundri landes
I wol nat do no labour with myn handes
Ne make baskestes and leue ther by
By cause y wil nat beggen ydelly
I wol noon of thapostles contrefete
I wol haue monye wolle chese and whete
Al were hit yeuen of the porest page
Or of the porest wydue in a village
Al shulde hir children sterue or for famyne
Nay y wol drynkyn lycour of the vyne
And haue a goly wenche in the toun
but herkenyth lordes in conclusiou
Your likyng is that y shal telle a tale
Now I haue y dronke a draght of corny ale
By god y hope y shal you telle a thyng
That shal by resou be at your lykyng
For thogh myself be a ful vicious man
A moral tale yit y you telle can
Which I am wont to preche for to wynne
Now hald your pees my tale y wol begynne

l.hi: First he repreuyth the vice of glotonye

div.l: In Flandres was whilom a compaignie
Of yonge folk that hauntedyn folye
As ryot hazard stewes and Tauernes
Where as with harpees lutes and gyternes
They daunce and pleye at des both day and nyght
And ete also and drynke euer hir myght
Thurgh whiche they doon the deuel sacrifice
With inne the deueles temple in cursid wise
By suꝓprofluyte abhomynable
Hir othis be so grete and dampable
That it is gresly for to heer hem swere
Oure blisful lordes sydes they to tere
Hem thoghte Iewes rente hym noght y now
And eche of hem at othris synne lowh
And right anon in Comyn Tumbesteres
Fetise and smale and yonge fruytesteres
Syngers with harpes baudes wafereres
Which be the verray deueles Officers
To kyndle and blowe the fir of leccherie
That is annexid vn to glotonye
The holy writte take y to my witnesse
That luxurie is in wyn and dronkenesse
Lo how that dronken loth vnkyndely
Lay by his doghtris two vnwetyngly
So dronke he was he nyste what he wroght
Herodes ho so wol the storye soghte
Whan he of wyn repleet was at his feste
Right at his owene table he yaf his heste
To sle the Baptist Iohn ful giltelees
senek seith a good word dowteles
He seith he can no difference fynde
Be twixe a man that is out of his mynde
And a man which that is drunkelewe
But that woodnesse fallyn in a shrewe
Ꝓproseuerith lengere than dooth drunkenesse
O glotonye ful of cursidnesse
O cause first of oure confusiou
O original of owre dampnaciou
Til crist hadde boght vs with his blood ageyn
Lokith how dere shortly for to seyn
A boght was thilke cursid vilenye
Corrupt was al this world for glotonye
Adam our fadir and his wif also
Fro paradys to labour and to wo
Were dryuen for that vice hit is no drede
For whil that Adam fastid as y reede
He was in paradys and whan that he
Ete of the fruyt deffendid on a tree
Anon he was out cast to wo and peyne
O glotounye on the wel oghte vs pleyne
O wiste a man how many maledyes
Folwen of excesse and of glotonyes
He wolde ben the more mesurable
Of his diete sittynge at his table
allas the shorte throte the tendre mough
Makith that Est and west and north and south
In erthe in eir in water men to swynke
To gete a glotou deyntee mete and drynke
Of this matere o pawle wel canstow treete
Mete vnto wombe and wombe ek vnto mete
Shal god destroien bothe as paulus seith
Allas aful thyng is it by my feith
To seyn this word and fouler is the dede
Whan man so drynkith of the whit and rede
That of his throte he makith his pryuee
Thurgh thilke cursid suꝓprofluytee
Thapostil wepyng seith ful pitously
Ther walken manye of which you told haue I
I sey it now wepyng with pitous vois
That ther ben enemys of cristes crois
Of which the ende is deth wombe is here god
O wombe o bely o stynkynge cod
Fulfild of dung and of corupciou
At either ende of the foul is the sou
How greet labour and cost is the to fynde
This cooke how they stampe and stryne and grynde
And turnen substance in to accident
To fulfille al thi likorous talent
Out of the hard bones knokken they
The mary for they casten naght a wey
That may go thurgh the golet softe and soote
Of spicerie of leef of bark and roote
Shal ben his saule y makid bi delyt
To make hym ȝit a newere appetit
But certes he that hauntith swich delites
Is deid whil that he leuyth in tho vice
a leccherous thyng is wyn and drounkenesse
Ful of stryuyng and of wrecchidnesse
O dronken man disfigured is thi face
Sour is thi breth foul art thou to embrace
And thurgh thi dronken nose semeth the sou
As though thy thou seydest ay sampsou Sampsou
And yit god wot sampsou drank neuere no wyn
Thou fallist as hit were a stiked swyn
Thi tonge is lost and al thyn honest cur
For dronkenesse is verray sepultur
Of mannes wit and his discreciou
In whom that drynk hath d
He can no conseil kepen
Now kepe you fro
And namely
That
Lokith the bible and nis ther ye may hit leer
look attila the greete conquerour
Dide in his slep with shame and dishonour
Bledyng ay at his nose in dronkenesse
A capitayn shuld leue in sobrenesse
And oủer/ree al this auiʆser/siri auisith you right wel
That was commandid vn to lamuel
Nat samuel but lamuel seide I
Redith the bille and fynde hit expressely
Of wyn yeuynge to hym that haue Iustise
more of this for hit may wel suffise

And there seyde I wol nat lese myn name
I wol nat take on me so gret deffame
You for tallie vn to non hasardours
Sendith sum othre wyse Ambassatours
For by my trouthe me were leuere dye
Thanne y you shulde to hasardours Allie
For ye that be so glorious in honours
Shul nat allie you to non hasardours
As by my wille ne as by my tretee
This wise philosophre thus seid he
looke ek that to the kyng demetrius
The kyng of parches as the book seith vs
Sente hym a pere of dies of gold in scorn
For he hadde vsid hasard ther beforn
For which he hild his glorie or his renou
At no value or reputaciou
Lordes may fynden othir maner pley
Honest I now to dryue the day away
Now wol y speke of othis false and greete

¶ How he repreuyth the vise of swerynge
gret swerynge is athyng abhomynable
And fals sweryng is yit more repreuable
The hye god forbad swerynge at al
Witnesse on Mathew but in special
Of swerynge seith the holy Ieromye
Thou shalt swere sooth thyn othis and nat lye
And swere in doom and ek in rightwisnesse
But idel swerynge is a cursidnesse
Be holde and se that in the firste table
Of hye goddis hestes honurable
How that the ij heste of hym is this
Take nat my name in ydil or amys
Lo rather he forbedeth swich swerynge
Than homicyde or many an othir thynge
I sey ek be ordre thus hit stondith
This knoweth that his hestes vndirstandith
How that the ij heste of god is that
And forthermore y wolle the telle al plat
That vengeance shal nat parte from his hous
That of his othes is coutageous
By goddes precious herte and by his nayles
And by the blood of Crist that is in hayles
Vijᵉ is my chaunce and thyn is cynk and treye
By goddes Armes if thou falsly pleye
This daggere shal thurgh out thyn herte go
This fruyt comyth of the bichet bones two
For swerynge ire falsnesse homycide
Now for the loue of crist that for vs dide
Letith youre othis bothe grete and smale
But sires now wol y telle forth my tale

this riotours thre of whiche y telle
Long erst or pryme rong or ony belle
Were set hem in a Tauerne to drynke
And as they sat they herde a belle thynke
Beforn a corps was caried to his graue
That on of hem gan callen to his knaue
Go bet quod he and axe redely
What corps is this that passith heer forby

Sere quod this boy it nedith neuer adel
Hit was me told or ye cam her . ij . houres
